titlePage.docImprint: ACT I .— The Church of the Nativity . Christmas Eve ,1918. ACT II .— The Goodkinds ’ Home . November ,1919. ACT III .— “ Overcoat Hall . ” October ,1920. ACT IV .— Gilchrist 's Room — “ Upstairs . ” Christmas Eve ,1920.

set.p: The action takes place in New York City .

div.head: ACT I .

stage.stage: SCENE : The Church of the Nativity . New York .

The set , representing only the chancel , is as deep as possible , so that , even when its foreground is brightly illuminated , the detail back of that is lost in shadows . Pierced by three fine stained glass windows , the rear wall looms above the altar , on which the candles are not lighted . In front of that is the sanctuary , and , in front of that , the communion rail , with three steps to the stage . Just right of these steps is a very tall and beautiful Christmas tree . The tree has been expensively trimmed , and has a practical connection for an electric-lighted ornament still to be placed at its top . Down R ., a door to the choir room , and , down L ., a door to the parish house and the street . These doors are exactly alike . Down L ., two folding wooden chairs that have been brought in for temporary use . A tall stepladder L. of the tree , facing front . Down R ., two wooden boxes of ornaments , that on top open and half emptied . There is a pile of tissue-wrapped and ribboned packages under the tree , and a general litter of gifts , boxes , and crumpled paper everywhere . The Church of the Nativity is fashionable and luxurious ; the effect of the set must be that of a peeping into a building spacious , magnificent , and majestic .

sp.speaker: AT RISE : Christmas Eve , 1918 . The act begins in bright
sp.p: day-light — about half past three in the afternoon — so that the early winter twilight may have set in before its end . The sun 's rays now come through a stained-glass window above the door L ., so that the R. of the stage is bathed in white , the C. in blue , and the L. in a deep straw . Two women and a girl are discovered . MRS. HENRY GILLIAM , bending over the box down L ., is fat , forty , rich and self-satisfied . Her daughter , DAFFODIL , commonly called “ Dilly , ” perched upon the ladder , is a “ flapper . ” As regards her mind , this means that , at twenty , she is wise and witty , cynical and confident , worldly and material beyond her elders . Physically , she is pretty , and , of course , has not hesitated to help out nature wherever she has thought it advisable . Considering what has been spent on her education , she is surprisingly ignorant and discourteous , particularly to her mother , who bores her dreadfully . LEILA THORNBURY is a divorcee ; thirty , smart , good-looking , with something feverish in her face , in her eyes , in her movements . Deliberately attractive to men , she is disliked , in proportion , by women . All three are very expensively dressed . Mrs. Thornbury has laid aside a fur coat on the cost of which twenty families might have lived a year . She is at the end of the stage , concerned with a number of dolls and other toys .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Turning with some ornament , on a level with her eyes she observes a generous view of DILLY 'S nether limbsDilly , for pity 's sake , pull down your skirt !As DILLY pays no attention , she continues to MRS. THORNBURYI do n't know what skirts are coming to !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: They 're not coming to the ground , mother . You can be sure of that !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: What I can n't understand is why our young women want to go around looking like chorus girls !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Perhaps they 've noticed the kind of men that marry chorus girls .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Salesmanship , mother , begins with a willingness to show goods .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Dilly ! Pull down your skirt !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: I can n't ! That 's all there is ; there is n't any more !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Holding up two dollsWhat are we going to do with these ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Despairingly surveying the profusionGoodness knows !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: I 've two engagements before dinner , and I 've got to go home and undress for the opera .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: I gave up a dance for this .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: A dance at this hour ?

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: People dance at any hour , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: What do they do it for ?

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: For something to do .To MRS. THORNBURYWe 're young and we 've got to have life and gaiety ; have n't we , Mrs. Thornbury ?

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: We 've got to have something . I do n't know what it is , but I know we have to keep going to get it .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: But you all waste your time so dreadfully . I 'm busy , too , but my life is given to the service of others .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: What could be sweeter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Dilly ! Nobody knows better than you that I 've never had a selfish thought ! Mr. Gilliam ——

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Of the Gilliam Groceries , Inc .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Mr. Gilliam says I 'm far too good !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: We agree with him , Mrs. Gilliam .

lg.l: Only yesterday I gave five hundred pounds of coffee and sugar to the
Salvation Army !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: And today father jumped the price of sugar to thirty-two cents !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Now — Dilly !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: With rising emotionOne gets precious little reward .... I can tell you ! I sent helpful thoughts from the Bible to all Mr. Gilliam 's employes ! Now they 're on strike , and the man that got “ Be content with your wages ” is leading the strikers !... Where 's the Star of Bethlehem ?To conceal her agitation , she has turned to the box .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: It does n't work , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Are those your husband 's men — on the front steps ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Oh , no ! Those are people from the sweat shops ! They 're starving , I hear , and Mr. Gilliam says it serves ‘ em right !Bringing forth a small caseWhat 's the matter with the Star of Bethlehem ?

lg.l: Oh , the usual ! Whoever heard of the lights working on a Christmas
Tree ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Holding up the starBut this must work . Mrs. Tice had it made to order — of Parisian diamonds . It cost a hundred dollars .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Reaching for the gewgawAll right ! It 's better than nothing !She takes it , and starts to ascendHold the ladder , mother ! It wiggles !MRS. GILLIAM obeys .

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: She has ribboned both dolls , and sets that just finished beside its companion on the chairThere !RisesI 'm half dead , and there can n't be any more presents !Starts up for her coatI 'd give my left hand for a cigarette !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Not here !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: I do n't know why not . We 've had almost everything else .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Mother 's so Mid-Victorian ! And ministers are finding they 've got to do something to make church-going attractive . What do we get out of it now ? I 've heard of preachers who go in for dances and movies , and they draw crowds , too . Naturally ! Who would n't go to church to get a squint at Douglas Fairbanks ?She has hung the starI 'm through !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Then come down .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Believe me , I 'm glad to get off this thing !She descends unsteadilyWhen I think I broke an engagement with the best fox-trotter in New York to do a shimmy with a ladder ——

div.stage: MR. BARNABY , package-laden , enters L. He is the sexton , and of the age , manner and appearance peculiar to sextons ] Oh , Mr. Barnaby !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Turns and is appalled at his burdenWhat have you got ?

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: Some more presents .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Good Lord !

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: Deposits his bundles on the steps L. C .Mrs. Tice brought them . She and Mr. Jerry Goodkind .MRS. GILLIAM nudges DILLYThey 're just coming in .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Sotto voceDilly , powder your nose !DILLY takes her bag from the communion rail , and obeysMr. Barnaby , our star wo n't light . Will you see if you can fix it ?MR. BARNABY 'S mind is on MRS. TICE . She is much too rich to open a door . He is edging L .

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: And Mr. Barnaby ——Voices off L .

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: One moment !

div.stage: He opens the door L. Enter MRS. TICE followed by JERRY GOODKIND . MRS. TICE has just entered middle-age , and refuses to shut the door behind her . Her wealth , which has given her an air of great authority , has made it possible for her to look a smartly-dressed young matron . The truth is that she is clinging to youth in an ever-lessening hope of “ keeping ” her husband . Beneath the “ air of authority ” is something cowed , and worried , and unhappy . Just so , beneath the smiling , careless surface of JERRY lies iron . He can be very ugly when he wishes , and he is always sufficiently determined to get what he wants , though he gets it generally by showing the urbane surface . JERRY would describe himself as a “ kidder . ” He is 35 ; sleek , well-groomed , and perfectly satisfied with himself . His most engaging point is a perpetual smile .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Hello , everybody !“ Everybody ” returns the greetingWho are those people on the church steps ? A lot of dirty foreigners blocking the sidewalk !

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: It 's the grating , Mrs. Tice . The furnace room 's underneath , and they 're trying to keep warm .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Well , let ‘ em try somewhere else !Recollection of unpleasant contact causes her to brush her coatI do n't mean to be unkind , but there must be missions or something !

div.stage: MR. BARNABY removes the coat , and then climbs to attend to the star

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: We did n't hope to see you here , Mr. Goodkind .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: I met him in front of Tiffany 's !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: The most dangerous corner in New York !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: And lured him here by mentioning that Clare Jewett was helping us .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Somebody page Mr. Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Dilly ! What a way of saying that Clare is engaged to the assistant rector !... Dilly 's looking well today , is n't she , Mr. Goodkind ? So young , and ——

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: And fresh .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Oh , boy !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Do come and see what I 've got for the girls of the Bible Class !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Testaments ?

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: That 's just it ; I have n't ! Bibles are so bromidic ! I want to give them something they can really use ! And it 's so hard to think of presents for those girls ; they 've got everything !Opening a small parcel she has withheld from MR. BARNABYGuess how I 've solved the problem !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: I can n't !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: I have n't an idea !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: I 'm dying to know !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Impressively . Displaying the giftSterling silver vanity cases !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Taking itHow ducky !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Charming !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: An inspiration !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Showing it to JERRYAll complete — lip-stick , powder and some nice , red rouge .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: CynicallyTo put on before you pray ?

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Precisely . To put on — before we — prey !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Gathering up her coatWell , good people , this is where I leave you !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: With the air of one bereftOh , Mrs. Thornbury !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: I 've done my “ one kind deed ” today , and I 've an engagement for dinner .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Permit me .Helping her .Some coat !

sp.speaker: MRS. THORNBURY
sp.p: Yes ... thanks .... See you all tomorrow at the Christmas Service ! Good-bye , everybody ! And Mr. Goodkind ! Miss Jewett 's wrapping things in the choir room !Everybody laughs . She exits L .

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: I 'll just try those lights .Exits L .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: She has an engagement for dinner , but you notice she did n't say with whom ! I do n't think they ought to allow divorced women in the church !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: VirtuouslyThe church wo n't marry them !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: That 's the trouble !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: IndicatingThe church will let ‘ em give stained glass windows !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Where does she get all her money ?

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Billy settled for thirty-six thousand a year !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: With growing amusementThink of getting thirty-six thousand a year out of munitions !... Gee , what a lot of lives that coat must have cost !

div.stage: Everybody laughs , and , on the laugh , enter DR. WADHAM . He is not the stage clergyman . On the contrary , he is a very pleasant and plausible person — plausible because he believes implicitly in himself . He has passed sixty , and has a really kind heart . But he has had no experience with life , and he has never been uncomfortable .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Hearing the door closed , looks around . SurprisedHere 's Dr. Wadham !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Why , Doctor !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: We did n't know you were back .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I did n't know you 'd been away , Doctor .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Shakes handsTen days ; attending a Conference on the Proper Use of Eucharistic Candles . It 's a subject on which I feel rather strongly .Turns R .It 's pleasant to see you , Mrs. Tice . And Miss Daffodil .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Is n't Dilly looking wonderful ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Quite wonderful !Glancing at the treeAnd what a beautiful tree ! The star lights up , I suppose .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Well , we have hopes !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Do n't let me interrupt . I 've only dropped in to keep an appointment with the wardens .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: We 're all through , except for putting these gifts under the tree .She busies herself with that taskMiss Jewett will be in with hers any minute .JERRY , who has been contemplating an excursion to the choir room , returns from the door , and helps MRS. GILLIAMThe star is real imitation diamonds . A gift from Mrs. Tice .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Joining DR. WADHAM L. C .Speaking of gifts , Doctor ——

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Yes , dear lady .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: My husband wanted me to have a little talk with you about his check .

div.stage: She pauses for encouragement , finding what she has been told to say a trifle difficult ] You know , he promised five thousand dollars to beautify the parlor of the Parish House .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Foreseeing troubleOh , yes .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: And since then — well , frankly , Doctor , John was very much upset about last Sunday 's sermon . Mr. Gilchrist preached from the text about the rich man entering the Kingdom of Heaven .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Always a trifle dangerous .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Yes , and last Sunday it seemed as if he were directing all his remarks at John . We 're in the first pew , you know , and John says he does n't like to complain , but there 's getting to be altogether too much of this — Bolshevism . John says the preachers are more than half to blame for the present social unrest . I heard the sermon , and I agree with John that some of it was positively insulting !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist is young .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist is a nut !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Do you know what he said , Doctor ? He said all this — “ decking the church ” — was making an accomplice of God . He said we could n't take credit to ourselves for returning a small portion of our ill-gotten gains !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Small portion ! When I 've just given away five hundred pounds of coffee !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: He said charity was n't giving away what you did n't want !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: It was good coffee , too ! Our second best coffee !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Of course , what John objected to was the reference to rents — to charging clerks and bookkeepers more than they could pay for “ wretched little flats . ” John says he does n't come here to be told how to run his business !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Quite right ! And I do n't pay seven thousand dollars a year to hear my husband 's coffee roasted !They all laugh — the more because of the previous tension . MRS. GILLIAM , surprised at first , sees the point , and joins in the laughter .Well , you understand what I mean !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: We understand , Mrs. Gilliam .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Personally , I 'm very fond of Mr. Gilchrist . His father had stock in our stores . But I do n't think he 's a good influence . This used to be a really exclusive church . Now , whenever Mr. Gilchrist preaches , there 's such a crush of undesirable people in the galleries you can hardly get to your pew . We do n't have that trouble with Dr. Wadham !

div.stage: CLARE JEWETT enters R ., her arms full of parcels . CLARE is 28 . Smartly dressed , though in a fashion that suggests thought rather than expenditure , and pretty , in spite of a certain hardness . The next sentence arrests her , and she stands in the doorway ; not eavesdropping , but not interrupting .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist was such a promising young man !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: So rich , and happy !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Tantalising JERRYAnd in love !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: He 's still rich , and in love , and , I think , he 's still happy .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I 've told you ; he 's a nut !

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: I wonder if that 's it . Do n't laugh ! He was n't like this before he went overseas as chaplain . Is it possible he was gassed — or something ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Here 's another armful of presents .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Oh , how do you do , Miss Jewett ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'm very well , thank you .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Starting to herHello , Clare ! This is a ——

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Intercepting him C .Surprise ! Ha ! And you 've been waiting for her half an hour !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: To MRS. GILLIAMI 'm afraid we 'll have to get Mr. Barnaby . There are so many packages .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Ca n't I help ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Will you , Doctor ? And Mr. Hinkle 's in there praying for someone to consult about the Christmas music .

lg.l: I told Mr. Hinkle the choir 'd better begin by singing , “ Peace , Perfect
Peace , With the Loved Ones Far Away . ”

div.stage: DILLY laughs and turns up L ., chanting “ My Wife 's Gone to the Country . ” Scandalized , MRS. GILLIAM hushes her .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: And , Doctor ! About the Parish House ... shall I tell my husband you 'll speak to Mr. Gilchrist ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Yes , I think you may even tell him that 's why we 're here today .He exits R .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Dilly , do hurry !

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: Ca n't I drive you home ?

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Thank you so much ! Good-bye , Miss Jewett . Good-bye , Mr. Goodkind . We must arrange for you to come up to dinner as soon as the holidays are over .He bowsDilly , say “ good-bye ” to Mr. Goodkind !

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Goodbye-ee !

div.stage: MR. BARNABY re-enters L. The door closing attracts MRS. GILLIAM

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: Oh , Mr. Barnaby , how about the lights ?

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: I think the trouble 's outside .

sp.speaker: MRS. GILLIAM
sp.p: You 'll be sure to fix it ?MR. BARNABY nods .

sp.speaker: MRS. TICE
sp.p: And will you put us in the car ?MR. BARNABY nods again , and goes L .I rather dread that mob at the door .She follows , groping in her bag for a bill to give MR. BARNABYGood-bye , Mr. Goodkind ... and Miss Jewett , and , if I do n't see you tomorrow , a Merry , Merry Christmas !

div.stage: There is a chorus of repetitions of this wish , amid which exeunt MRS. TICE , MRS. GILLIAM , DILLY and MR. BARNABY .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: It 's funny to find you in church .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Why ? My father 's the senior warden .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Laughs and takes up a parcelWhatever else you inherit , Jerry , it 's not likely to be religion !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Religion does n't trouble the old man much — except Sundays . I came here to see you .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You 've been avoiding me .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Nonsense ! Come help me with these parcels .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I want to talk to you .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: That 's just it , Jerry . You always want to talk to me , and always to say something I do n't want to hear .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Simply , but not very surelyI 'm in love with someone else !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You 're what ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Looking defiantly into the mocking face quite close to hers and , this time , with convictionI 'm in love with someone else !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You 're in love with Clare Jewett !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You 're very rude . I 'm engaged to Mr. Gilchrist , and he loves me , and believes in me , and your sense of decency and fair play ...

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Inherited from my father ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: should keep you from proposing to a woman who 's going to marry ...

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You 're not going to marry Mr. Gilchrist .He lounges against the ladder .What 's the use bluffing ? We 've known each other since childhood . You know I 'm not going to give up anything I want because it belongs to somebody else . And I know you 're not going to give up what you want — comfort and luxury — for a crazy man who wears his collar hind-side before !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Jerry !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Now that 's admitted , let 's go on .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist is n't exactly poverty-stricken !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No ; he got quite a lot of money from his father . You like him and when you said “ yes , ” you thought you were getting somebody you liked , and all the rest of it , too . But something 's gone wrong with Gilchrist , and you know it !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Why do you say that ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Because , if you did n't before , you heard this afternoon . I saw you standing in the door . And I 'm going to tell you a few things more !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I do n't want to listen !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Maybe — but you will ! Do you know that your young trouble-hunter has given away nearly one-tenth of his capital in three months ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: No , and I do n't believe it !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: All right ; ask my father ! The old man has his money in trust ! Gilchrist wo n't touch his income from Gilliam Groceries , because they 're profiteering , and he 's preaching such anarchy that both wardens are coming this afternoon to complain to Dr. Wadham ! I do n't want you to throw yourself away on a raving bug !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: And your advice is ——

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Marry me . I 'm a nice fellow , too — and I can give you what you really care about . You 're over your ears in debt , without any chance of paying up — or cutting down . And you are , shall we say , twenty-nine in October ? I know what it cost you when your father died , and you had to come down a peg . You do n't want to keep on — coming down , do you ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: And so — you advise me to marry you ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Looking at him squarely and significantlyKnowing all I do know about you ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I do n't see how that concerns you .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: It proves you do n't love me .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I want you , and I 'm offering marriage to get you .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You have n't said one word of love .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I 've said : “ What 's the use bluffing ? ” I 'm no movie hero — and no crazy dreamer . I 'm a little shop-worn , perhaps — maybe , a little soiled — but I 'm sane , and I 'm solvent . You 're good-looking , and smart , and a lady . You 'll help my standing and I 'll help your credit . For the rest — we need n't bother each other too much .... What do you say ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I say it 's — revoltingly — sordid !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Looks at her an instantAll right !Takes out his watch , looks at that , and crosses to L .You think it 's sordid at 3. 45 on Christmas Eve . Well , keep your ears and your mind open , and see how you feel in the morning . My telephone 's six nine four two Rhinelander — and this is the last time I shall ask you !Puts his hand on the knob

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Wait !He turns backWhatever you believe of me , I love Mr. Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Rhinelander six nine four two .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: And , what 's more , I 'm going to marry him !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Rhinelander six nine four two .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Jerry , I think you 're the most detestable person I 've ever known in my life !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: LaughingRhinelander six ... nine ... four ... two !

div.stage: He exits L ., leaving CLARE humiliated and fuming . She stands still a moment , and then starts to exit R. At the tree , she throws down the parcels she is still carrying , and , as she does so , DR. WADHAM re-enters R .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Why ... Miss Jewett !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'm nervous !... I want to finish up and go home !

div.stage: She exits R. DR. WADHAM looks after her ; then picks up the parcels . JERRY 'S father , GEORGE GOODKIND , enters L. He is about the Doctor 's age — sixty — but he has had vast experience with life , and he enjoys comfort now because he has been very uncomfortable . GOODKIND is much like any other successful business man you might meet — and like — at dinner . He is brisk and economical of time , but pleasant , and , unless his interests are involved , extremely amiable . He does what he conceives to be his duty by his family , his community , and his God , and feels that all three should appreciate it .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Ah ... Mr. Goodkind !Glances at his watchYou 're early !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: How do you do , Doctor ?Puts down his hatWalked out of a meeting . I do n't like letting religion interfere with business , but I wanted to get here before Benfield . It 's about young Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Shall we go into my study ?

lg.l: Benfield 's coming here , and I 've only a few minutes . Did you know
Gilchrist proposes to preach a Christmas sermon about the strike ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: What strike ?

lg.l: This garment strike . He announced his subject from the pulpit , and
Benfield 's furious .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Mr. Benfield is n't interested in clothing .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: No , but he 's invested heavily in my West Virginia coal mines , and down there we 're on the verge of the biggest walk-out in our history . You see what I mean ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: The labor problem 's none of the church 's business . Or any outsider 's business . It 's a worrisome subject , and there 's no good stirring it up . That 's what you want to tell Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: I have told him ... frequently .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And what 's the answer ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: He says every problem ought to be the church 's business , and that , until the church becomes a power in live issues , it is n't a power in life !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: He wo n't listen to reason ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: No .

lg.l: Then he 'll have to listen to something else . If he persists about this
Christmas sermon —
lg.stage: BARNABY enters L. GOODKIND turns . Impatiently
lg.l: What is it , Barnaby ?

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: There 's a man out there wants to see Mr. Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: What kind of a man ?

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: IndifferentlyA poor man . I think he 's a Jew .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Who ever heard of a poor Jew ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist is n't here .

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: I told him that , but he wo n't go away . I wanted to ask had I better send for the police ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Oh , I would n't do that !

sp.speaker: MR. BARNABY
sp.p: Why do n't he go over to the Synagogue instead of hanging around a Christian Church ? Mr. Gilchrist gave this fellow his overcoat . I suppose he 's come back for the gloves !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Tell him I 'll speak to Mr. Gilchrist .MR. BARNABY shakes his head despairingly and exits .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Well , there you are , and what I wanted to talk about privately is ... what 's got into the boy ? Has he gone crazy ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: I 've asked myself that . I 've asked myself if what he saw in France ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Exactly . A lot of young fellows go off the handle and start out to reform the world , but this lad has run through twenty thousand dollars in less than three months !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: In addition to his salary ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Yes . I could understand if he 'd spent the money on himself , but he has n't ! He 's given it away !DR. WADHAM shakes his headGilchrist 's father was my first partner , and I got the boy in here , and I feel responsible for him . As trustee , I can refuse to turn over another penny of his principal , and , as senior warden , I can demand his resignation from this church . But I want him to have every chance . Tell him if he 'll get a grip on himself , and reconsider tomorrow 's sermon ——Enter BENFIELD L .Here 's Benfield !

div.stage: “ CHARLIE ” BENFIELD is fifty , and a “ rough diamond . ” He is self-made , and proud of it , though nothing really good — nothing of education , or refinement , or knowledge and appreciation of fine things — has gone into the making . He is arrogant , domineering , used to having his own way , and to sweeping aside obstacles . He comes in with his hat on his head , and it is a minute later , when DR. WADHAM 'S glance makes him aware of the fact , that he removes it .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Hello , George ! Howd'y ’ , Doctor ! Am I late ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: BENFIELD 'S very presence makes him nervousWe 've been waiting for you . Had n't we better retire to my study if we 're going to discuss Mr. Gilchrist ?

lg.l: We 're not ! We 've been discussing long enough ! All I got to say now is :
Gilchrist leaves this church or I do !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Now wait a minute !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Is n't that a little mandatory ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: I do n't know what it is , but it goes ! I 've worked hard all my life , and now this fellow gets up and tells me what I 've worked for is nothing , and that I 'm nothing , and all my ideas is wrong !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: He did n't say that .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Oh , yes , he did — last Sunday and every Sunday ! I 've got two million dollars tied up in Black River mines , and I 'm not paying to have the socialist papers down there print that my own minister is in favor of strikes !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Wait a minute , Charlie ! That 's not the tone to take to Dr. Wadham ! We all feel that Gilchrist has gone too far , and we 're agreed ——

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Does he preach tomorrow ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: We 're agreed that if he insists on preaching about the strike ——

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: He goes ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: He goes !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: All right . And if he do n't insist ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: He stays .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: And I go !He gets his hat and returns . DANIEL GILCHRIST enters L .You can decide which of us is the most valu'ble to your church ! Because I tell you again — and straight — this church ai n't big enough for Gilchrist and me !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: SmilingA church that is n't big enough for two little men , Mr. Benfield , must be somewhat crowded for God !

div.stage: BENFIELD cannot trust himself to answer . He jams his hat upon his head , and exits L. GILCHRIST is 33 . He was a football hero at college , and shows it . He was a gentleman before he went to college , and he has been one ever since , and he shows that , too . What he does n't show is what one expects in a “ reformer ” — narrowness , hardness , something forbidding . An ascetic , beyond doubt , self-denial has only made him trim and fit . The goodness that shines in his face is partly good humor . He has honest eyes , with fire in them , and there is strength and zeal back of that — strength and zeal that will leave their mark later . As yet , his exaltation is chiefly in his smile . His great gift is charm — and sympathy . At this moment , he wears no overcoat , and is glowing from the cold . Still smiling , he looks after BENFIELD .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: EmbarrassedMr. Benfield is a little — ah — a little ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes ; a little .

div.stage: GOODKIND crosses for his hat , and observes DANIEL , who is chafing his wrists .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Pneumonia weather , Daniel ! Where 's your overcoat ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Outside .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Oh , yes . There 's a man out there , too , who says he wo n't go ‘ way until he sees you .He joins DANIELDan , you 're an awfully decent fellow , but I still think you made a mistake going into the church . If you ever want to talk it over with me , I 'd be glad to help you — any time ! You know that ! Good-bye , Doctor ! Good-bye , Dan , and a Merry Christmas !He exits L .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Daniel , you 're in trouble .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: SmilingDoctor , I 'm used to it .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: This time it 's serious . I 've warned you often . I do n't see how you can have been so blind .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I have n't been blind .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Then you do n't care for your position in this church .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: With feelingThere 's only one thing I care for more .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: And that is ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: To be worthy of it .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: When you 're as old as I am , Daniel , you 'll understand that being honest does n't necessarily mean being disagreeable .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Does n't it mean — telling the truth ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Do you know the truth , Daniel ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes ; do n't you ? Does n't every man — in his heart ? And if we want to keep it in our hearts , and never think about it or look it in the face , should n't someone pry open the door and cry : “ Behold ” ?... I did n't tell them anything they did n't know , Doctor . I do n't know anything they do n't know . I just reminded them ——

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Exploding on the last wordThat we were heathen !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That we were Christians , and every man our brother , and that we were sitting , overdressed and overfed , in a Christian Church , while our brother froze and starved — outside — in a Christian World !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: That is n't fair ! These good people have given ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Given — what cost them nothing ! Frumpery and trumpery and diamond stars ! That 's how all of us give — what we do n't need ; what we do n't even want !... You 're a good man , Doctor , and , honestly , what would you say tomorrow if your wife told you she 'd sold her rings , and given the money to the poor ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Why , I ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You 'd say she was crazy !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: But there 's no necessity ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes , there is ! There 'll be people lying in the parks tonight . What would Mrs. Tice say if I invited them to sleep in her pew ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: That there 's no reason why she should share dirt and disease !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Exactly ! We may believe in the brotherhood of man , but we know about germs ! We 're not sure what is truth , but there 's one thing we are sure of , and mean to be sure of , and that 's our own comfort ! You know that , and I know it , and they know it — but we must n't say it ! All right ; in God 's name , what are we to say ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Who has been nervously regarding this raving as confirming the worst fears of MR. GOODKINDPrecisely . And that brings us to tomorrow 's sermon . I understand you intend to talk about the strike .Dan nods “ Yes ”And that 's not a very pleasant subject for Christmas . Would n't it be more fitting to preach from the text , “ Glory to God in the Highest ” ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: “ And on earth , Peace , good will toward men ” ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: DelightedYes ! You might say , “ There are many kinds of peace —— ”

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: But there are n't !

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: There is physical peace — peace that came with the end of this cruel war !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: There is no peace ! There is only fear — and hate — and vanity — and lust , and envy , and greed — of men and nations ! There are only people preying on one another , and a hungry horde at the very doors of your church !... My text will be : “ And Peter followed afar off . ”

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Into his tone , hitherto indignantly human , comes something mystic — something divineWe all follow — afar off .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Alarmed ; not at the words , but at that “ something divine ”Daniel ... my dear fellow !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Do n't worry . I 'm quite sane . Only — I 've been wondering about that for a long time .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Wondering ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What would happen if anybody really tried to live like Christ .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Shaking his headIt can n't be done .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Is n't it worth trying ? Men risk their lives — every day — in experiments far less worth while . We 've had centuries of “ fear , and hate , and greed ” — and where have they brought us ? Why not try love ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: How can you make them try ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: By showing that it would work .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: It wo n't work , Daniel . It 's a beautiful ideal , but it wo n't work . Times have changed , and things are different . Life is n't as simple as it was two thousand years ago . The trouble with you , Daniel , is that you 're not practical .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I wonder .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: And the great need of the church is practical men . We must n't take the Scriptures too literally . We must try to interpret their spirit . And , above all , we must please our congregations , or we sha n't have any . And then what becomes of our influence ? Better fall back on my text for tomorrow , Daniel .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I can n't .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: At least , you must promise not to discuss the strike .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I can n't do that , Doctor .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Or else let me take the pulpit .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I wo n't do that !A pause .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Very well ! Preach your Christmas sermon , and afterward ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: I think you may find a greater field of usefulness elsewhere .A long pause . The men look at each other , and then DANIEL turns away to conceal his emotion . He goes up for his hat , and returns .I 'm sorry , Daniel . I know you 've been very happy in your work here . I know how failure hurts . But you saw it coming , and you would n't turn aside .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He looks up with flashing eyesThe man who turns away from his vision — lies !Shakes handsIt 's all right , Doctor .He crosses L. CLARE JEWETT , ready for the street , enters R .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: BrightlyWell , Miss Jewett !DANIEL hears the name and stops . He is consoled by her very presenceWhat 's happened to the choir ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Mr. Hinkle cut his finger . I 've been applying first aid .

sp.speaker: DR. WADHAM
sp.p: Woman 's traditional mission — to bind our wounds .He turns to exit , and sees DANIEL . He is struck by the double significance of his remark , and the timeliness of CLARE 'S arrival .Well , I must be going ! Step into my study in the morning , Daniel , and we 'll have a look at your sermon !He exits L. From here the lights dim very slowly .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I hope I never see another doll ! Got anything on your mind , Dan ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: QuicklyWhat do you ——

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I mean anything special to do ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh !— No .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Take me home .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He beamsI 'm getting my Christmas present early !Gets his hat .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Where 's your coat ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Outside . That is — I lent it to a friend . Oh , I 've got another — somewhere !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: But you can n't go out without a coat .Looks at wrist watchAnyway , I told the taxi man to come back at half past four . That 's the worst of not having a car . Well , we may as well sit down !He assists her , but his mind is afar .What 's the matter with you , Dan ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Nothing important .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: There will be if you insist on going around without an overcoat !Looking at him narrowlyYou 're too generous .He is still afar .I say you 're too generous ! How are we going to be married if you go on giving things away ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: LaughsIs generosity a fault in a husband ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: That depends . Is it true you 've been giving away — well — large sums of money ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Who told you that ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: A little bird .He laughsAnd that you 've refused to take part of your income ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Little bird tell you that ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Must have been a cuckoo !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Is it true ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: About the money ? Yes .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Well , there 's the strike , and a good deal of unemployment , and I 've got so much . Why — I 've got you !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: RisesLet 's not talk about it now .She turns L. Hesitates ; looks at her wrist watch ; looks off L .Yes ; let 's !— You 're so changed . I hardly know you . We do n't seem to want the same things any more .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What do you want , Clare ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I want to be happy .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's exactly what I want !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: How can anybody be happy without money ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: How can anybody be happy with it ? Anyway , do you think people are ? Happier than the people who just have enough ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: In our day and age there 's nothing worse than poverty ! There 's nothing more degrading than having to scrimp , and save , and do without , and keep up appearances ! I 've tried it ... ever since my father died ... and I know ! I can n't do it any longer , and I wo n't !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: She turns away , and comes back somewhat calmerI do n't want to quarrel with you , Dan . I just want you to be sensible .... I love you , but I love the good things of life , too . I like to be warm and comfortable .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You can be sure of that .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: But that 's only the beginning . I want good clothes , and furs , and my car , and money to spend when I like . I want my own house , and my own servants , and a husband who amounts to something . I 'm no different from other women of my class .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I hoped you were .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: A year or two ago people thought you were going to be a Bishop . Today you 've made an enemy of every influential man in the church . All that may be very noble , but I 'm not noble , and I do n't pretend to be . I do n't feel any call to sacrifice myself for others , and I do n't think you have any right to ask it !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I do ask it , Clare .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You mean you 're going on like this ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I mean I can n't give you expensive clothes , and servants , and a big house while all about us people are hungry .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: What do you propose to give me ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: A chance to help .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: To help wash the dishes , I suppose , in a three-room flat in a side street !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: And to visit the sick , and befriend the friendless .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: A charming prospect !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: It really is , Clare . You do n't know how happy we can be with work , and our modest plenty . There 's so much to do — and they wo n't let me do it here . We 've got to get near the people in trouble , and we can n't with a big house and all that . I do n't think we shall come to a three-room flat .He smilesWe 'll have five or six rooms , and our books , and each other .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I can n't believe you 're serious . You 've always been a dreamer , but I can n't believe you 're going through with this fantastic nonsense !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 've chosen a narrow path , dear , but I hoped it might be wide enough for us both .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: It is n't . With your means and opportunities , you 're offering me what any bank clerk would give his wife . I thought you loved me , but you 're utterly selfish , and I think a little mad . You 've a right to throw away your own life , but you 've no right to throw away mine .She hands him his ringOur engagement is off .A pause . She starts for the door , and then hesitates , looks at her wrist watch , waits for him to call her back . When he does n't , she returns .Do n't you think you 're making a terrible mistake ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Looks up from the ring . SimplyNo .CLARE turns again , this time quickly and with resolution , and exits L. The church is quite dark , except for light streaming from the open door R. DAN looks at the ring , and puts it in his pocket . With his back to the audience , he looks at the altar of his church . Suddenly , from R ., the organ is heard , playing “ Hark the Herald Angels . ” He crosses and closes the door . In the blackness , he hears a step . THE POOR MAN has come on through the open door L .Who 's there ?... Are you looking for someone ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'm the assistant rector ... Mr. Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: I know you , Mr. Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes ; I remember . You 're the man who was cold . Can I do anything for you ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: I think you can .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Let 's have it then .

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: Perhaps I can help you , too .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: In what way ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: In my way .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: My poor man , I wish you could !

div.stage: His despair impels him to confide in anyone ]: I was so sure of what I wanted to do , and now I begin to wonder if it can be done !

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: It has been done .

lg.l: But in this day — in this practical world — can any man follow the
Master ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: Why not ? Is this day different from any other ? Was the world never practical before ? Is this the first time of conflict between flesh and spirit ? If it could be done then , why not now , and , if it was ever worth the doing , why not now ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: But how ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: We have been told how .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: “ Take no thought of the morrow .... Sell whatsoever thou hast , and give to the poor .... Love thy neighbor as thyself .... Bless them that curse you , do good to them that hate you . ” But if a man did those things today people would think him mad !

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: What does it matter ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He would lose everything !

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: And gain everything !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What good can one man do ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: Why do n't you try ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He tried , and they crucified Him !

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: Did they ? And if they did , what does that matter ? Is a man dead whose ideal lives ? Ye crucified me , but I am with ye alway , even unto the end of the world !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: In God 's name , who are you ?

sp.speaker: POOR MAN
sp.p: I am a Jew !

div.stage: As he speaks , slowly the tree and everything beneath it is illuminated by the Star of Bethlehem . The light , dim at first , grows stronger and stronger , its rays revealing sanctuary and picking out the points of the cross on the altar . But where the POOR MAN stood is nothing . There is no one there . The spirit — if spirit it was — has disappeared . The man — if man it was — has gone . DANIEL gives a cry , and , as he does so , the light is extinguished , and suddenly , to the music that has been heard faintly through the door R. during this scene , the full choir sings : “ Hark the Herald Angels Sing . ” In black darkness
THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT II .

stage.stage: SCENE : GEORGE F. GOODKIND 'S Library . New York .

Ten months later . The set has only two essentials — a wide , curtained , glass door L ., and an ordinary , heavy wooden door down R. The first gives entrance to the music room , which is indicated rather completely when the door is open . The second , by way of a hall and a flight of stairs , leads to the main entrance of the house . For the rest , the library is a shallow room , very much like any other library in the home of any other rich and well educated man . It is a little richer and more luxurious than most , perhaps , with — here and there — priceless things from palaces in Venice or art collections in Rome . The obsession of business is suggested by various utilities , transient and otherwise — a row of law books , a small file , and a pile of papers upon the substantial library table .

sp.speaker: AT RISE : It is a Saturday evening in November , 1919 . The
sp.p: GOODKINDS have been entertaining informally at dinner , and , having finished the chief business of the occasion , the company is now diverting itself in the music room . This room is brilliantly illuminated ; one sees the shadow of a man leaning against the glass door . DILLY GILLIAM , at the piano , is playing one of the syncopations popular at the time . After a moment , a servant , with a card tray , enters R ., crosses and exits L. An instant later , GOODKIND , in evening clothes , enters L. He has a card in his hand . The SERVANT re-enters , re-crosses , and re-exits , stopping , en route , to switch on the lights . GOODKIND looks at the pile on the table , and turns the topmost paper face down . BENFIELD , also in evening clothes , enters L .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: What the h ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Shut the door .

div.stage: BENFIELD does so . As he returns , GOODKIND gives him the card

lg.l: “ Labor conciliators . ”

div.stage: Throws the card on the table

sp.speaker: What the h ——
sp.p: GOODKIND What are labor conciliators ? Mostly thugs . When you 've been director in a coal mining company a little longer you 'll know . We 've got a million dollars ’ worth of ‘ em handling this strike .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Police duty ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: No ; spies and agents provocateur . I hate the breed , but what are you going to do about it ? This fellow , Max Stedtman , got into the union five or six years ago , and now he 's one of the delegation they 've sent up to me .... Where 's Jerry ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: I gave him the high sign .

lg.l: BENFIELD
Thanks .... Why did n't you go down to West Virginia ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Had to look over that power plant in Canada .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Oh , yes !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Anyway , what do I know about coal mining ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: You 're president of the company .

lg.l: Yes , but that means digging up money — not coal . I 've never set foot in
West Virginia in my life ; and I do n't want to !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Yes , but in a serious situation like this —

lg.l: I sent Jerry . Jerry has a dozen qualifications and no scruples . And
I sent Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Who has scruples and no qualifications .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Thus striking a balance . I mean that ! Do n't make any mistake about Gilchrist . He 's a valuable man . I did n't hire him because I was sorry he got fired out of the church ... and only a little because I knew his father . I hired him because he had theories , and I wanted to try ‘ em out !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: I 'll say he 's got theories !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Yes , and the remarkable part of it is ... sometimes they work . They worked up at that power plant . A year ago I would n't have taken it as a gift . Gilchrist applied a little soft soap —

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Soft soap or gold dust ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Well , both ; but , damn it , Charlie , with all the increased wages and decreased working hours , the plant 's making money now for the first time !

div.stage: Enter JERRY L. He is a little sullen — the result of brandy and resentment . He , too , is in evening clothes , and he closes the door behind him .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: There 's something in Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Mostly bugs !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: All right !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I told you what he was doing at the mines . Now he wires you , “ Everything settled if you accede to rational conditions , ” and up comes this delegation ! What are the conditions ? I 'll tell you now — surrender ! You 're crazy if you see these workmen ! We 've nothing to discuss ! They 're our mines , and we 'll run ‘ em as we like ! If this philanthropist of yours carries out instructions we 've got ‘ em whipped !... What was the idea of the high sign ?

p.stage: As BENFIELD picks up the card to answer

sp.speaker: Stedtman
sp.p: JERRY

sp.speaker: Where ?
sp.p: GOODKIND

lg.l: JERRY
Of course , we 're leaving our guests flat !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Your wife 's in there !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Clare resents our talking business at home .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Resents — and you have n't been married a year ! Palaver 's a wife 's job ! They oil the machinery while we shovel in coal !The SERVANT re-enters R .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Mr. Stedtman .

div.stage: Enter MAX STEDTMAN . He is a wiry little man , with the face of a ferret and the furtiveness of a rat . His nervousness does not indicate lack of self-confidence . That quality has made Stedtman the man he is today . For the rest , he is 40 , and faintly Semitic . The SERVANT exits .

lg.l: How do , Stedtman ? This is Mr. Benfield — one of our new directors .
You know my son .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: NodsSaw him down to Black River .

div.stage: They sit — JERRY down L .; BENFIELD left of the table ; GOODKIND back of it ; STEDTMAN R .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Well ... the committee 's on its way .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Who 's in this delegation ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: I 'm chairman . We got a Pole called Umanski .

sp.speaker: Umanski
sp.p: STEDTMAN He 's a radical . You can n't do anything with him . But there 's a fellow named Joe Hennig ....

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Who 'll listen to reason ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: I think so .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: He 's got a pretty wife .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: What the he ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: What has that to do with it ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Lots . Pretty wives like pretty things . Hennig 's in debt , and this girl 's on his neck every minute . She 's a peach . You know her , Mr. Jerry !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Pearl Hennig ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Oh ! I thought I saw you talking to her onct . Anyhow , Gilchrist knows her ... well .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: You mean ....

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: I mean I would n't mention Gilchrist to Joe Hennig .BENFIELD whistles .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: That 's rot !

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Anyhow , Hennig and me are two votes , and I figure Hennig 's 'll cost about ....He looks at them narrowly .fifteen thousand dollars .

div.stage: All three show surprise .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I do n't like bribery .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Not when it is n't necessary .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And Gilchrist wired yesterday : “ Everything settled . ”

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: On conditions .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Yeh — on their conditions ! Take it from me , this Gilchrist has double-crossed you !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: I told you !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: He 's a ....

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Goes right on , without heeding the simultaneous interruptionHe 's been at union meetings ! He got ‘ em to send this delegation , and he tried to get ‘ em to turn down Hennig — our one best bet ! You take it from me —

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: QuietlyI wo n't take it from you , Stedtman .Looks aroundOr from anybody else . I know this man .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: CowedWell , he 's gone around talkin ’ compromise . Compromise ai n't no way to settle a strike . Givin ’ ‘ em confidence . Why , we got a couple o ’ hundred representatives among the workmen tellin ’ ‘ em they got no chance . We got special police clubbin ’ ‘ em every time they try to hold a meeting . You would n't believe what we done down there in the way of harmony !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: It 's all been done before .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Never no completer ! We 're workin ’ the black list and , if a man opens his mouth too wide at a meetin ’ , somebody — he do n't know who — tips the gover'ment that he 's a “ red . ” We got ‘ em so they ai n't sure of their own brothers . We 're postin ’ bills , in seven languages , saying : “ Why should workmen mistrust the company ? This is the land of opportunity ! America is calling you — GO BACK TO WORK ! ” The boss has a scheme now to start a riot between the Poles and the Wops ! And you know the end o ’ that ! Troops , and scabs , and machine guns ! What stopped it ? One gent that do n't know nothin ’ about harmony , or co-operation , or nothin ’ — except hangin ’ around after a skirt ! If you got to descend to bribery now , do n't blame me ! Blame Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Rises ; striking the table with his open handHe 's absolutely right !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: RisesOf course , he 's right ! Wha 'd'ya expect of a man kicked out of his church for Bolshevism ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: He ought to be brought back right now !

lg.l: He 's coming back —
Yes ; what is it ?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Two men to see Mr. Stedtman .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Good !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Bring them in .

div.stage: Servant exits

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Now look — do n't try nothin ’ before Umanski ! Just give us an excuse to vote right , and then we 'll go out , and get rid of him , and I 'll slip back with Hennig ! Now then —His sharp ears have heard footsteps off R. He strikes a poseIt 's very good of you gentlemen to see us ! I was goin ’ to meet my friends outside —The Servant ushers in UMANSKI and JOE HENNIG , and retires— but you been so kind and agreeable — Hello , Joe !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Hello , Max !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: You said you be on sidewalk .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: I just really got in myself . This is Mr. Goodkind . He 's the President . And a couple o ’ Directors . Well , now we can get down to business !

div.stage: He sits . UMANSKI stares in amazement at his temerity . UMANSKI is a giant Pole or Russian . Whatever flesh he ever had has been starved off ; he is all bone and brawn . In his face is something strangely like poetry ... something born of silence and suffering . He is in his best , which does not obliterate the picture of the man in working clothes , his sleeves rolled up over his muscular arms . Hennig is a stocky man of 45 — a “ grouser . ” His tone has none of the courage , the dignity , the independence of UMANSKI 'S ; he blusters , emptily , an echo , without much to say , and one guesses he might be made to bluster either way . There is a pause .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Smoke ?He presents the humidor to HENNIG , and STEDTMAN , rising , reaches out and helps himself . GOODKIND goes on to UMANSKI , who does n't unfold his arms ; does n't even appear to see the box . GOODKIND returns , and sets it lower right end of table .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Coming down R. of GOODKINDI guess you know all about our grievances .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I did n't know you had any .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You did n't know we had any ——

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Ah , you fellows are never satisfied !

lg.l: You 're getting plenty for what you do ! What are you complaining about ?
You 've left good jobs to follow a lot of idle , discontented agitators !
We 've got to win this fight on principle ! The work 's there ! I pay what
I can get men for , and not a cent more ! Take it or leave it !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: We got to hang together to get anything !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You 're hanging , and what have you got ?

div.stage: The piano music in the next room , which ceased during the scene with STEDTMAN , is succeeded now by the low tones of a violin . UMANSKI speaks , in a voice as unemotional as its owner is stolid .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I work twelve hours — every day ... thirty years ... got nothing .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Why should you have ? An untrained man —

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You do n't even know English !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: How I gonna learn English — work twelve hours a day ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Nobody asked you to take the job ! Nobody asked you to come over here ! You 're not an American !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I was American .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: SneersWhen ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: When I fight ... in the war .A short pause .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Turning to GOODKINDWe 're not getting anywhere . We 've been over this a dozen times !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I wanna chance to learn ! I wanna chance to live ! I wanna see ... sun !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Wha 'd'ya mean — son ?Together

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Your son ?Together

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: God 's sun . I never see him . Go to mines — him not up . Work in mines — him not see . Go home — him gone . Got baby five years ago . Never see him . Go to mines ... him , not up . Come back — him asleep . Go home one day — him gone .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Dead ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: My wife say : “ Good ! Not such many to feed ! ”

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: When you worked you had enough to eat , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Yes . Work twelve hours a day and got enough to eat — so can work some more . Always work . Get up — work — come back — sleep — get up — work . Never got time to talk to wife — never got time to talk to nobody — never got nowhere . Never save nothing .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: WhiningIt ai n't fair !JERRY takes out his cigarette case .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: That little box — what you pay for him ?Jerry turns front , not deigning to answerAh , I know ; gold . You pay more for him than I got from swing pick thirty years . Me and six families — we live in one house you own . We got one room upstairs ; two down cellar . Sleep there . Eat — cook — wash upstairs . See nothing but brick yard , and clothes hang up to dry . Wife — she carry water from yard . Me — I carry potato peeling out front . Him rot . If I do n't like that , I quit — and starve !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You want to live on Fifth Avenue !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: And then you 'd find something to kick about !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: If I do n't like other mans will . Other mans take my job . I got little girl twenty years old . Awful nice little girl . Got gold hair . Got blue eyes . Her take sick . She sorry she 's sick . She wanna go church . She ask me : “ Pop , buy me new dress for church . Buy me pretty pink dress . ” Where I get him ? We hire doctor once , and he say : “ Air — sunshine — milk — eggs ! ” Where I get air — sunshine — milk — eggs ? Got no job . My little girl , she cough , and cough , and one night she die . I tell you we got right to quit ! We got right to hang together ! We got right to fight — to live — and , by God , we gonna fight — we gonna live — we gonna — BY GOD !

div.stage: The music stops . In the same short instant , there is a patter of applause ; more music — lively this time — and , bursting into the room from L ., DILLY runs into UMANSKI . She has gold hair ; she has blue eyes ; and what is more , she has a new dress . It is a “ pretty pink dress , ” too , and its owner wears jewels worth the ransom of a dozen Umanskis .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: As she entersNow , look here , Jerry ; you 're not going to — Oh ! I 'm sorry !UMANSKI looks at her ; then covers his face , and , with a great sob , drops into a chair R. C. STEDTMAN puts his arm about the man 's shoulders . GOODKIND , C ., stares at him sympathetically .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You 'll have to wait , Dilly .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Ask the ladies to stay in the drawing room . We 'll join them in a few minutes .

sp.speaker: DILLY
sp.p: Yes .... Certainly .... I 'm SO sorry !

div.stage: She exits . A pause . STEDTMAN , one arm about UMANSKI , uses the other to signal GOODKIND to go ahead . GOODKIND ignores him .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I think we 'd better let this go for tonight .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: RisingOh , no ! Me — I 'm all right ! Excuse !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You 're a little upset , and I have guests . Besides , Gilchrist will be here in half an hour , and I want to talk to him before I say anything definite . Suppose we all meet here tomorrow at noon .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Who has turned down angrily at mention of the nameNot Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: No ; just we six ... and , maybe , one or two more of our directors .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: All right !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I wanna know what we gonna do — tonight !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: We 're going to get together . You fellows have got the wrong idea . We 're not tyrants , or monsters . We 're Christians , and we want to act like Christians . Only ... we 've got to live , too . We 've got to have the things we 're used to , just as you have . But I think I can promise , if the strike 's called off , you men will be kept , and put back just where you were .... Ring the bell , Jerry .

div.stage: JERRY does so . A pause .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: I guess you do n't want me any more .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Thanks .

div.stage: Exits L. A pause .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: To HENNIG . Making conversationYou live in Black River ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Married ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You betcha ! Prettiest girl in West Virginia ! We only been married a year . I got her in the five-and-ten-cent store .... I mean , that 's where she was working . She 's at her sister 's now ... up to Pittsburg . Left the day before I was elected to come here .ProudlyI sent her a telegram !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You do n't say so !To JERRYAnything the matter with that bell ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: The man 's busy , I suppose . I 'll show them out .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: If you will .... Well , good-night !

div.stage: He shakes hands with HENNIG , and with STEDTMAN , but , when he comes to UMANSKI , that giant is immobile . His slow mind has been thinking out the earlier declaration .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: What about this here twelve-hour day ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: We 'll consider that after the strike 's called off .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: And the twenty-four-hour shift ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: We 'll consider that , too . Meanwhile — you go back just where you were !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Then what good we gain by strike ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Nothing 's ever gained by quarreling . You 'll find that out some day .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Some day something be gain ! Some day we gonna win ! This — he do n't go on always ! You see !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: InsolentlyAre you ready ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: As HENNIG slips out R ., UMANSKI looks at JERRY with contempt .You see !Exits R .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Significantly ,— in a loud whisperWe 'll be back later .He exits R .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Swine !

div.stage: He exits R. GOODKIND , obviously worried by the interview , goes to the table , and rights the topmost paper . Looks at it . Sits , and examines other papers . The SERVANT enters R .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Did you ring , sir ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Half an hour ago .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Indicating a boxI was signing for this .GOODKIND , writing , does n't look up .Can I do anything for you , sir ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Yes .... Get me a drink .The SERVANT hesitates . GOODKIND takes key from pocket and gives it to him . The SERVANT unlocks a cellarette , up R ., takes out decanter and glasses , relocks the cellarette , comes down L. of table , sets down the tray , and returns the key .Thanks .The SERVANT starts to exit L .And , Riggs !The SERVANT stops up L. C. Enter CLARE L .If Mr. Stedtman comes back tonight ... with one of the other men ... I 'll see them in here .

lg.l: Very good , sir .
This package just came for you ,
Madam .
lg.stage: He gives her the box , and exits L. A pause .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Everybody gone ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: They 're all down in the billiard room . We wanted to make up a couple of tables at bridge , but , with the men in here ... as usual .... Where 's Jerry ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 've seen him just ten minutes this week .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: He 's only been back three hours .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Well ... I wish he would n't break up my dinner parties .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Pushes back papersWhat have you got there ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Looking at the boxAnother ... substitute ....

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Substitute , for what ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: As she opens itFor my husband 's time ... and love ... and companionship .Holds up a sable scarfSables .She gives it to GOODKIND .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Looking at it with admirationMm ! You do n't seem much surprised .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: No .... Whenever Jerry 's been away longer than usual , or done something he 's a little ashamed of , there 's a box from Cartier or Revillon .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Must have been a whopper this time !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Seriously . WonderingYes .She takes the scarf .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Pretty generous husband ... if you ask me !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yes .She puts the scarf away .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Upon my word , I do n't know what you women want !... A man works his heart and soul out to get you things , and still you 're not satisfied !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Maybe we 'd like a little “ heart and soul . ”

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Heart and soul , and what a man trades ‘ em for ! You want your husband to succeed , and give all his attention to you ! You want him to have plenty of money , and plenty of time ! You 're willing to take everything , but you 're not willing to pay for it !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I suppose everybody must pay .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Surest thing you know ! You women are all alike . My poor wife — she had everything , and I used to catch her crying in a corner . We never seemed to understand each other ... after we got this . She was a good wife , too , but the best of you never seem to want what you have .... Sometimes I think we do n't any of us really want what we struggle so hard to get . Sometimes I think we 're all wrong !He looks at his watch , and rises .Well , I guess I 'll go downstairs !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I wish you would .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Goes to herYou 're not crying ?She nods and looks upMy God ! Can you beat it ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'll be down in a minute .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Tell Riggs — will you ?— if any one comes , I 'll be ... talking to Jerry .He puts his hand on her shoulderAnd ... buck up ! There are people worse off than we are ... and it 's a great life if you do n't weaken !

div.stage: He exits L. CLARE goes C. She puts the box , with its contents , on the table , dries her eyes , and is powdering her nose when DANIEL GILCHRIST opens the door R. He is in business clothes , and starts to retire when he sees CLARE . He would a little rather avoid the interview .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Come in ! I 'm just powdering my nose . Does that offend your reverence ?

lg.l: On the contrary ; I agree with the man who said , “ Put your trust in
God , and keep your powder dry . ”

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: When did you get in ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Half an hour ago .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Had dinner ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: On the train . I was starved . Thank goodness , they do n't charge for dinner by the mile !... Riggs said your father-in-law was in here .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: He 'll be up in a moment ... wo n't you sit down ? We have n't had five minutes together since ——

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I understand you 're very happy in your new ... profession .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Sits .Yes .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You 've got ... everything ... you want ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No , I have n't everything I want , but I 'm happy .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: My father-in-law says if you settle this strike you 're to be — but that 's a business secret .A pauseI suppose I might tell you .A pauseHe says it 'll make you a big man in the company ... with a tremendous salary .... You must n't give it away !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: The secret ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: The salary ... I suppose you 've got over that .... So ... you do n't really seem to have lost anything by giving up your church .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No . Queer as it seems , sometimes I think I 've gained ... in opportunity .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Chiefly to herselfPerhaps one might have eaten one 's cake and had it , too .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You frightened me so that night , with the bugaboo of poverty . Do n't you think there might have been a compromise ? Something half way ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why open wounds that are beginning to heal ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yours seem quite healed .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: And you have everything you want ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You see ... I was selfish ... to ask you to give up the things that count so much with you for those that count with me .... Afterward , when I knew you were to be married ... I was afraid for you ... and I was wrong again .He risesYou 're happy ... and I 'm honestly glad !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Are you ... honestly ... happy ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Honestly .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: In just helping others ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: In just helping others .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I do n't understand that .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You will ... some day .

div.stage: JERRY enters R. He has added two or three brandies to a generous allowance at dinner , and though not drunk , is sullen and quarrelsome . The more so at finding DANIEL with CLARE ] .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Hello , Gilchrist ! In early , are n't you ?Crosses .I did n't mean to interrupt a tête-à-tête !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You 're not interrupting .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Where 's father ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I thought he was with you .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I stopped for refreshments .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I see you did .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Laughs and turns to DANIELWe 've been having a genial evening with your delegation . That 's why my wife 's sore .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'm not “ sore . ” I 've been a little lonely .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: You do n't look it !... I could n't help going to Black River ! I did n't go for pleasure ... did I , Gilchrist ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No . There was work , and plenty of it . I was sorry you had to leave when you did .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Why , Jerry did n't leave much before you , did he ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Just a few ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: At the same timeOnly twenty-four hours .... He wanted to get back to you .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: But ... he 's just got back .... Where have you been , Jerry ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Attending to business ... of course !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Of course .She takes the scarf from the box on the tableGood night , Dan .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: CheerilyGood night !She starts to door L .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Oh ... you got the furs !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yes ... thank you .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Do n't mention it !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'm very grateful ... but ...

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: But what ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Never mind . We 'll talk about it some other time .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: We 'll talk about it now !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'll go .Starts R .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No , you wo n't ! You made a crack about my leaving twenty-four hours before you did ! How do you know when I left ?To CLAREIf that 's what you 're sore about , for heaven 's sake , drop it ! I 'm sorry you 've been alone , and I 've sent you a handsome gift as an apology !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I do n't want it .She lays down the scarf .I do n't want to be paid for shutting my eyes to any insulting thing you choose to do !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: And I do n't propose to be made a blackguard before strangers !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Dan is n't a stranger . And I do n't want to make you a blackguard . Only ... since you 've insisted on the truth .... Dan , when did my husband leave Black River ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I have n't seen him since Thursday .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: There you have it ! He has n't seen me since Thursday ! Does it occur to you that may have been because he was n't in Black River ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: As a matter of fact , I was n't .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Oh !... Where were you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: At the mines .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Is that the truth ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
