sp.p: Of course it 's the truth ! And , if it was n't , I do n't see that you 've any right to ask questions ! I have n't done anything that was n't in the bargain ! I have n't done anything every man does n't do !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Every man ... perhaps ... but one !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Gilchrist ! My God ! Now we 've got it ! If you 'd only married him ! He 's good , because he says so ! You ought to 've been here a minute ago ... when the company detective warned us not to mention Gilchrist to Joe Hennig !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You mean ——

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I mean Pearl Hennig !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Pearl Hennig ? Why , you — you know that 's not true !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I know it 's not true !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Do you ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Off R .Say ... now ... listen ... you behave yourself !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Off R .Behave ... hell !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Continuing above these voicesAsk Stedtman ! Ask Hennig ! And before you make up your mind where I was yesterday , ask where he was ——

div.stage: Enter STEDTMAN and HENNIG , followed by the SERVANT . There is no dead cue for this entrance . They come on — STEDTMAN trying to hold back HENNIG — flinging open the door as HENNIG says “ Hell ! ” HENNIG confronts GILCHRIST .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You — Gilchrist ! Where 've you got my wife ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I have n't got your wife , Hennig .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: The hell you have n't !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You 'd better go , Clare .

lg.l: I want her to stay .
All right !
What 's it all about , Stedtman ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: You can search me ! Umanski stuck to us all the way home . When he left , I went in to have a little talk with Joe ... alone .... See ? There was a telegram , and he read it , and ——

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: And came here to ask Gilchrist : Where 's my wife ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: She told me she was going to her sister 's .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: She ai n't never been near her sister , and you know it ! I just got this from her sister !Holds out wire . JERRY snatches it .Read it !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: ReadingPearl ai n't here . We ai n't seen her . Ai n't she home ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Maybe she is .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You know she ai n't ! And what if she is ... now ? I do n't want your leavings !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why do you say that , Hennig ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Why do I say it ? Ai n't I seen you down town with her ? Ai n't I found you with her when I came home unexpected ? I knew you was stuck on her , and I warned you to stay away ... did n't I ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You were mistaken .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Did n't I warn you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: And you came again ... did n't you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Every man but one !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I went first on your account ... because they told me you were in debt ... and why . I “ came again ” because she asked me to . This disappearance looks queer , I admit , but people do get lost , or hurt , and taken to hospitals , and are n't identified .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Half convincedYou think ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I think your wife 's all right , Joe . I do n't think you ought to accuse her publicly until you 're sure she 's not .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: CriesHow 'm I gonna be sure ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Suppose we ask the police to look for her ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Turning quicklyWhat 's the use of starting a hulla-ba-loo ? You do n't want the woman accused publicly , but you 're willing to spread the news so this man 'll be ashamed to go back home . We all know the facts in the case , and the least said about it now the better .To JOEYou 've found her out . Let her go ... and forget it !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I do n't think he ought to forget it .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: No . I do n't think he ought to drop it now ... until we all know the truth .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Right !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I want to know the truth ! I got to ! I been crazy about her ! Maybe that 's a good idea ... the police . I got to know the truth !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: At bayAll right ! Stedtman ! Where were you yesterday ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: At the mines .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: What part of the mines ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: All over .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Did you see Gilchrist ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: No .

div.stage: DANIEL never takes his eyes off CLARE . He watches her , as the net tightens around him , observing , with ever-increasing agony , that he is convicted in her eyes .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: When did you see him last ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Thursday —— Yes , it was Thursday .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: In Black River .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Alone ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: With whom ?

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: With Mrs. Hennig .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I knew it ! I 'm gonna kill you !

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No , you 're not . You 're going to keep quiet . But you wanted the truth , and you 've got it . I 've known it all along .To CLARENow do you think I was lying ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I do n't know . I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Oh , yes , you do ... only you wo n't admit it !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I suppose that 's it .

div.stage: She takes her scarf and starts wearily to exit L .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare !She stopsI do n't care what anyone believes but you !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: TurnsI 'll believe you , Dan , if you 'll only explain .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I forbid you to speak to my wife !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Go on , Dan .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I forbid you to speak to my wife !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Exploding ... to JERRYIf I had n't anybody to think about but you !

div.stage: They stare at each other ... close together . Suddenly , JERRY lifts his open hand , and strikes DAN across the mouth . DAN starts to retaliate , but controls himself , opens his clinched hands , and lowers his head .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: In almost speechless amazementDan ; you 're not going to take that ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I have nothing to say .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I did n't think you were a coward . You see , I was wrong about everything .

div.stage: The scarf in her hand , she exits L. A short pause . Suddenly , JOE , emboldened by what he has witnessed , certain of DAN 'S cowardice , breaks from STEDTMAN and rushes at GILCHRIST .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You 'll play around my wife , will you ?DANIEL merely looks at him .You will ... will you ?... Take that !He strikes out . DANIEL seizes his wrist , and , with one powerful , dexterous movement , hurls him to the floor

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: As HENNIG struggles to his feetI hope I did n't hurt you , Joe .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Looks from DANIEL to JERRYMy God !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: RetreatingDo n't worry ! I 'll get you ! It may be a long time , but I 'll get you !He exits .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: With great kindnessTake him home , Stedtman .STEDTMAN looks to JERRY , who jerks his head toward the door .

sp.speaker: STEDTMAN
sp.p: Good-night , Mr. Jerry . Tell your father we 'll be around ...DANIEL turns and looks at him . He backs toward the door .in ... the ... morning !

div.stage: Quick exit . He closes the door , which has been left open by HENNIG . The two men look at each other . JERRY goes to upper left of table , and pours himself a drink .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Well , you 've made a nice mess of it ! Why can n't you keep your nose out of other people 's business ? Why did you have to date my leaving Black River ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why did you have to get mixed up with Pearl Hennig ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: I can take what I want out of life !

lg.l: You can . God says : “ Here is the world . Take what you want ... AND PAY
FOR IT ! ”

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Rubbish !DrinksSave your preaching for those that like it !Comes downAnd keep away from my wife !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Because you 're in love with her ! Are n't you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Well , you 've a hell of a nerve to preach to me about Hennig 's wife while you 're making a play for mine .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'm not making a play for yours .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: No ? You expect me to believe that when you admit —— Why did you pull that hero stuff ? Why did you keep your mouth shut when I lost my temper ? Why did you turn the other cheek ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You would n't understand , Jerry .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: Would n't I ? Well , you understand that I 've forbidden you to speak to her and that goes . If you come here again , I 'll have the servants throw you out , and I 'll tell my father why .GOODKIND enters L .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Here 's your father now .

sp.speaker: JERRY
sp.p: And that 's not all I 'll do !

div.stage: Lowering his voice ]: Not by a damned sight ! [ He wheels about and exits .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Taking cigars from humidorSmoke ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Thanks .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Looking off after his sonJerry do n't like you much , does he ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Not much .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Lights his cigarWell ... how are things in Black River ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I think we 've got everything settled .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Fine ! Benfield 'll be up in a minute , and we 'll hear the conditions !He sits in an easy chair L .Somehow , I knew you 'd do it ! Jerry says you 're a philanthropist , but I knew he was wrong !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Thanks .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: If you 've really settled this strike ... our way ... your salary from today is thirty thousand a year !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Thanks ... again .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 'm dog-sick of rowing with labor ! It 's such utter damned waste !... Excuse me !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I agree with you !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 'd hate to figure what walk-outs have cost this country !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes . I often wonder why it would n't be cheaper to keep the men contented .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: How 're you going to do it ? Do n't forget there are as many people paid for stirring up strikes as for crushing ‘ em ! Paid well , too ! What the laboring man needs is a real interest in his job !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why do n't you give it to him ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND How ? By doubling his wages ? The more most of ‘ em get
sp.p: the less they want to do for it ! You know that !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: They 've got a notion that you get rich by riding around in a limousine !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Do n't you ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Not often ! Not unless you think while you ride ... or your father thought for you ! Even then , money does n't stay long in bad company ! To hear those fellows you 'd think there was n't any work , except what 's done with a pick ! The man that really produces is the man with the idea !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: The man that produces most .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Yes , and he ought to get most !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He does !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: He always will ! Show me a big man and I 'll show you somebody who 's done a big job ! It 's the little man with no capacity and no chin that cries about a conspiracy to keep him from being President !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: There 've got to be little men , too , Mr. Goodkind .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And they 've got to be satisfied with little rewards ! We can n't all have the same bank-roll any more than we can all have the same health ! That 's where unions go wrong ! When you tell a man he 's going to have the same reward , whatever he does — not because he 's got ability , but because he 's got a union card — down goes the standard , out goes incentive , and to hell goes the whole social structure !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Right !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: That 's why I 'm fighting the unions ! Not because I want to starve the man who works , but because I want to fire the man who does n't ... and reward the man who does ! I want to give every man a good reason for doing his best ! You can talk equality and democracy all you like , Dan , but the minute the average man is n't afraid of being fired he is n't afraid of being worthless ! The minute you take away incentive — the chance to get this — that minute you reduce the world to a common level of common indifference and common futility !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Right !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: RisingHave another cigar !DANIEL shows the one he has just lighted , and shakes his head .Where the hell 's ——He turns , and sees BENFIELD standing in the door L .Oh , Benfield ! Come in ! Gilchrist has settled the strike !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Good !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Giving a folded document to GOODKINDThere are the terms .GOODKIND sits L .They may seem a little radical , but I think I can show you they 'll save money in the end !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: That 's the idea !

div.stage: With the paper in his hands , being opened , he feels confident and cocky . To BENFIELD ]: I told you I knew my man ! The Lord knows he 's full of theories , but sometimes they — [ His eye falls upon a disturbing line ] Wait a minute ! What 's this ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: What 's what ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Reading“ Hereby agreed ... the men are to be represented ... on the board of directors .... ”

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: StunnedNo ! !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Yes ! And ... look here !Reading“ All disputes ... referred ... to a committee of arbitration .... ”

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: The man 's gone crazy !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: When you 're through ....

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Reading“ One-half of all profits , over and above a fair dividend , to be divided pro rata , according to wage and length of service . ”He risesWhy ....Words failWhat is this ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Jerry told you ; it 's surrender !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No ! No ! It 's justice !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: It 's nothing ! It 's a scrap of paper until I sign it , and I would n't sign it if I had to shut up every mine in West Virginia ! Why should I ? We 've got ‘ em licked !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: If you 'll only let me explain ....

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Explain what ? They 're licked ! They sent a delegation up here , and we 've won over the delegation !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You mean you 've bought the delegation !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Who said so ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Jerry .... Not ten minutes ago he referred to Stedtman as the company detective . We both know Hennig 's for sale . Buy him , and I 'll go back and tell them he 's bought , and prove it !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: You 're working for us !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'm working for ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Wait a minute , Benfield ! We 've all lost our heads ! Daniel and I have just been over all this , and he admitted I was right !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Right as far as you went , but you only went part way ! You have a right to a profit on your idea , and your investment , and the labor you put back of it ! The public has a right to coal , and transportation , and all it needs and pays for ! But , above everything else , the workman who works honestly has a right to something more than the barest kind of a bare living ... and it can all be done if you do n't sink everybody 's rights to accumulate a fortune you do n't need and can n't use !... All the argument on earth can n't make you all right so long as there 's a Umanski in the World !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: If these people succeed there 's no limit to what they 'll do !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: If they fail there 's no limit to what you 'll do !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: There 's no good transferring control from the intelligent few to the ignorant mob !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: There 's no good in anything so long as we fight each other like beasts , instead of helping each other like brothers ! There 's no hope anywhere except in The Great Teacher , and the understanding that what He taught was not only good morals , but good sense and good business !

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: Highfalutin nonsense !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Daniel does n't realize what he 's costing us !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Millions !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , is that all ?

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: All ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Am I costing you one cigar ? Am I costing you one blanket from your warm beds , or one stick of furniture from your comfortable homes , or anything else you 'll ever miss ? I 'm taking nothing from you , and I 'm giving thousands of men like you a chance to live !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You 're costing yourself your last chance of success !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I do n't want your kind of success ! I 'm through ! I give you back your job , as I gave you back your church , and I give you twenty-four hours to sign that paper !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: If I do , you 're finished !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I am when you 've signed !He goes R .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: If you walk out of that door you 're throwing away the chance of your life !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'm keeping my soul !He opens the door .

sp.speaker: BENFIELD
sp.p: You Judas !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You damned fool !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Good-night !

div.stage: DANIEL closes the door behind him .
THE CURTAIN FALLS .

div.head: ACT III .

stage.stage: This room — not too large — was the “ front parlor ” of a comfortable residence in down-town New York . Business , of the least attractive sort , and the slums long since have occupied the district . The building is a red-brick , low-stoop , English-basement house . The rear wall , which is the front of the dwelling , is pierced by two lofty windows , through which are seen the top of an iron railing , and a row of similar structures , fallen into decay , across the street . Between these windows , upon a low marble shelf , now holding a tray of cups and saucers , originally was a tall , gold-framed mirror . Over this hangs a blackboard , upon which has been chalked : “ And so , to the end of history , hate shall breed hate , murder shall breed murder , until the gods create a race that can understand . ” Beneath the right window is a big radiator . Down stage R. are folding doors , partly open , or a large single door — whichever shall prove advisable . These — or this — lead to the main hall , and so to the basement , or upstairs , or to the front door , which slams solidly whenever it is closed . Left is a decrepit , white-marble mantel , with a “ fake ” fireplace . In front of this — in a jog , perhaps — a small platform , of the kind used in public schools . Upon this , a small table and a chair . Down stage of it , a geographical globe , suspended over which a wall-pad informing us that today is Wednesday . Above the mantel-shelf , another blackboard , upon which are some simple calculations , and the axiom , “ Luck is work . ” In the center of the room is a long library table , with a brown cover , and with numerous kitchen chairs about it . On the table a reading lamp , a bowl of yellow , purple and brown chrysanthemums ; and numerous books and magazines . Gilchrist has succeeded in making the old place comfortable and inviting . It is a combination of club , settlement house , school , reading room and lecture hall . Brown linoleum covers the floor , and there are brown denim curtains over the windows . A history chart hangs on the wall . There are book-shelves , and two or three big , comfortable chairs ; a phonograph and , perhaps , even a motion picture machine .

sp.speaker: AT RISE : It is just after seven o'clock on a brisk evening
sp.p: in late October , 1920 . Grubby , seated down stage of the center table , is concealed behind a copy of “ The Woman 's Home Companion , ” which he has opened wide , and , holds in front of him . Mack , a shabby ne'erhYpppHeNdohYpppHeNwell , between thirty and forty years old , opens the doors R ., and peers in uncertainly . Reassured by the character of the room , he enters , and looks about him curiously . Even from the rear , it is evident that Grubby is a person of no authority , so Mack dismisses him , temporarily , and warms his hands over the radiator . Next he inspects the quotation between the windows , pauses at the phonograph , and arrives in front of the platform L. The three words on this blackboard interest him . He reads them , turns away , turns back , and reads them again . At last , he sniffs contemptuously , and , completing his circuit , stops on the left of Grubby .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Hello ... you !GRUBBY lowers his paper , and reveals a sixty-year-old face , round , very red , and framed in a scraggly gray beard .Is this Overcoat Hall ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: I 'm looking for Mr. Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: He ai n't in , but he will be .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Are you working here ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Is anybody working here ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Mary Margaret .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Who 's she ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: A girl .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: What girl ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: The girl that cleans . A lame girl . Her mother 's the janitor . Have a seat . Somebody 'll be along in a minute .

div.stage: And he resumes his magazine ... never completely abandoned . Mack , thrown upon his own resources , picks up one periodical after another , but Fortune does not smile . They prove to be “ The Atlantic Monthly ” ... “ The Review of Reviews ” ... “ The Scientific American . ”

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: What are you reading ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: A piece about “ Better Babies . ”

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: LaughsAre you going into the baby business ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: No . I was a hansom driver .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Handsome !The laugh becomes uproarious .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Ah ... hacks ! I drove hacks ... man and boy ... forty years . Then taxis come in , and I went out !

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: What 'd you do then ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Took to drink .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Yeh ; then drink went out .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: What 's your job ?

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Well , I was in the movies . That is , I was going to be , but the fellow that was going to put up the money , his mother did n't die , after all .... Before that , I sold bricks ... a few weeks . I sold books , too . And life insurance . I never had any luck . Who wrote that , “ Luck is Work ” ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Well , it is n't ! I 've worked at fifty things , and look at me ! I figure the world owes me a living , and here I am , waiting for a bite of grub and an overcoat ! Is it true the boss 'll give you an overcoat ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: He will if he 's got one .

lg.l: That 's what a fellow told me . He said that 's why they call this
Overcoat Hall .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: I suppose a hard-luck story 's the proper spiel .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: You do n't get no chance for a spiel . He do n't ask you nothing . You just come , and help yourself , and talk things over ... if you want to . Coffee and sandwiches every night — and suppers and sermons on Wednesdays .

lg.l: Preaching !
lg.stage: Looks at the wall pad , and reaches for his hat .
lg.l: Wednesday . I 'll be back Thursday .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Not regular preaching ! Just talks ! Sometimes they 's a picture show ... but the pictures is rotten ! No shooting , or nothing ! But you can always sneak a little snooze ‘ til you get to the hand-out !

div.stage: MARY MARGARET enters through the open door R. Her two crutches are rubber-tipped , so her invasion is noiseless . She occupies herself with the cups and saucers C. MARY MARGARET is fifteen , and pathetically pretty . The conspicuous feature of her costume is a pair of soiled gold slippers that once set off a ball gown .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Do n't he try to reform you ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Naw ! The way he talks , you 'd think you was as good as him . He says to me , the other night , he says , “ You 're a good man yet , Grubby , ” he says . “ You 're strong and healthy , ” he says , “ and , if you learned to drive a taxi , all the best people in New York would be telephoning for your cab . I 'll lend you the money , ” he says . Gee ; he almost had me started !

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: What 's the catch ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: There must be graft in it somewhere .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: If you ask me , I think the poor gent 's got a few nuts in his nose-bag . A little bit batty . That 's what I say !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Turning downAnd that 's what you got no right to say , Grubby !

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: To MACKMary Margaret .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: He 's been good to you , ai n't he ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: That 's why we think he 's nutty . What 's he do it for ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: ‘ Cause he loves you .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: What for ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: God knows !She has brought down a cup and saucer , with other utensils , and is clearing and setting a place at one end of the table . With this exclamation , she locates the cup somewhat forcibly .After seven o'clock now , and the meeting in half an hour , and he ai n't had a bite since morning !

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Where is he ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: He went to see a man that killed himself .MACK laughsI mean ... tried to . It was in the papers this afternoon , and Mr. Gilchrist says : “ I want to talk to that man . ”MACK 'S interposition has brought his words to her mind , and reflecting on them , she explodes .Graft !! Why he did n't have the rent money yesterday , and he was desprit ! He ai n't had money to get himself a pair of shoes , and nobody helps him , or comes near him , but you bums that roast him behind his back !GOODKIND appears in the doorway R .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: I did n't roast him . I just said he was crazy .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: CrisplyMr. Gilchrist ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: He 'll be here any minute . Wo n't you come in ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Thanks .

div.stage: He comes forward a few steps , and looks at GRUBBY , who , after an instant , takes refuge behind his Home Companion . GOODKIND crosses to MACK , who turns up stage . He surveys the blackboard . MARY MARGARET finishes her task .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Offering a periodical to GOODKINDTake a magazine , and sit down .With a nod , he accepts .I got to go make the coffee .To GRUBBYYou can come and carry it up in about fifteen minutes .She turns and catches MACK filching a loaf of sugar .Graft !! ... Well , you ought to know !She exits R ., singing “ I 'm a Pilgrim . ” By now , GOODKIND is reading in a big chair L. MACK glances at him , and comes down to GRUBBY .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Think she 'll tell him ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Naw ! Anyway , he do n't care ! He says we 're all brothers in God .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Gee !

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: That 's what he told Jimmie Curran — brothers in God — and Jimmie just up for pinchin ’ a guy 's pants . Jimmie lives across from his room upstairs , and Jimmie says he 's clean loco .GOODKIND notes name and address on the margin of his magazine .Guess what he 's got in the back yard !

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Tennis . And handball games for children . And , in the other two houses , he 's got flats ... with bathtubs ... and the rents ai n't what they ask now for stalling a horse . Why would n't I say he was crazy ? Everybody says so but Mary Margaret !

div.stage: DANIEL enters R. He is shabby , but beaming . He carries two books , which he lays on some piece of furniture up R .; after which he removes his overcoat , and hangs it over an old umbrella already suspended from a wall-rack down stage of the door .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Hello , Grubby ! You 're early ! And you 've brought a friend ! That 's fine !He shakes hands with MACK .You 're very welcome !Sees and crosses to GOODKINDAnd Mr. Goodkind ! Well ! You 're welcome , too !Shakes handsHave you come down to look us over ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: His eyes indicating the othersI 've come down on personal business .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes !TurnsGrubby , there 's a box of books in the hall . How would you and your friend like to ——

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: I promised to help with the coffee .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I see .GRUBBY exits . To MACK , who has been stealing surreptitious glances at the overcoatAnd you ?

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: I just wanted to speak to you a minute .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: All right . After the meeting .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: I wanted to ask you ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: After the meeting !Turns back to GOODKINDSit down .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: SittingThanks .

div.stage: MACK — resentful , unobserved , uncertain of getting the coat honestly — is sorely tempted . One pull , one step , and he is safe from work and denial . During the following , standing almost in the doorway , he is drawing the garment toward him .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: To GOODKINDI 'm glad you dropped in tonight , because I 've been intending to call on you , but there 's so much to do here —The coat comes off the rack , and with it , the umbrella , which falls with a crash . Both men rise , discovering MACK , coat in hand .Hello ! I thought you 'd gone .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: No ; I — I — wanted ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You wanted my coat .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Advancing with a glad smile of pretended relief that DANIEL has found the simple explanationYes ... that 's what I wanted to ask you .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'm so glad you said so .MACK shows surprise .Because , if you had n't and I had n't understood , you might have been tempted to take it without asking — and then you 'd 've been so sorry and ashamed . A man could n't come into another man 's house , and be welcomed , and then take the other man 's coat , without losing his self-respect ... could he ? And , of course , if we 're going to pull ourselves together , and get out of a hole , we must keep our self-respect .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: I would n't steal ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You could n't .... It 's your coat .... You asked for it , and I gave it to you .... When you 've worn it ... into a good job ... come back and help me give another to someone who needs it as you do .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Of course you will .Helps him into the coat , and then shakes his hand .Good-night .

sp.speaker: MACK
sp.p: Hesitates , amazedGood-night .DANIEL turns L ., and with a gesture expressive of the conviction that this man is mad , MACK exits .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Well , I 'll be damned !DANIEL laughsHe wo n't come back ! Not one in ten would come back !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: All right !... That coat cost twenty dollars . If one in ten does come back , we 've made a man for two hundred dollars . Is n't it worth the price ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Maybe ... if a man 's got the price ! Have you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Like our friend ... that 's what I wanted to ask you .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: It 's not what I wanted to ask you .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'm rather badly in need of money , and my father ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Your father understood you well enough to leave you only an income . I foolishly turned over some of the principal , and , in three months , you threw away twenty thousand dollars . You could have had a big salary , and you threw that away . You 're an utter damned waster — if you 're no worse !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What do you mean ... worse ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You 'll soon find out what I mean ! You 've had my son 's wife down here , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Once or twice .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Or three times ... or a dozen ! He knows !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 've asked her not to come again .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And he 's asked her ... but she 's coming when she likes . She says so . Because she 's in love with you .... God knows what women see in your kind of man ! There was Pearl Hennig ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Please !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Oh , my son told me ! And I hear ... in the neighborhood ... that you 've worse women than that running here ! Women of the streets !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Not many . They 're welcome , but they do n't come .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Well , that 's your business ! And if your neighbors get sick of having a resort of this kind in their midst , and drive you out , that 's your business ! But my son 's wife ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Is her business !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And his ! Only Jerry 's in no condition to settle the matter ! He 's broken down from worry and overwork , and you 're partly responsible , and that puts it up to me ! You can take this as a final warning ! If you see Clare again , I 'll act , and I 'll act quick ! That 's all ! Good-night !He gathers up his coat and hat , and crosses to the door .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Waking from a reverie , and turning R .Oh ! Mr. Goodkind !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Expecting capitulation . Comes down R .Yes ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: How about the money ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You 've had what 's coming to you !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: But that 's nothing ! I pay half that for these crazy houses ! And I 've gone terribly in debt fitting them up !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: With bath tubs and tennis courts !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: People must have baths .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: These dirty immigrants !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: The dirtier they are , the worse they need ‘ em . I want to show them how to live , and I want to show other people that you do n't have to make a pigpen to make a profit !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Are you making a profit ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Enormous ! And , to go on , I 've got to have twenty-two thousand dollars .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Oh , is that all ? Twenty-two thousand dollars to go on making a fool of yourself ! Well , you wo n't get it !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Not even as an advance ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Not a penny !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Do n't drive me to ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: To what ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Rather at a lossTo ask for an accounting !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Hardly believing his own earsTo ask for ... WHAT ?This is the last straw .Now listen to me ! I 've stood all I 'm going to stand ! You 've run amuck ! You 've become dangerous to yourself ... and me ... and the neighborhood ! You 're going to stop it , and you 're going to stop now !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's your mistake .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Is it ? A year ago you gave me twenty-four hours to sign a paper , and I did it , and it cost me two million dollars ! Tonight I give you thirty minutes to shut up this place , and quit seeing my daughter , and if you do n't do it ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: As I wo n't !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 'll be here inside of half an hour with a doctor !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Then we 'll file a petition to have you declared incompetent !He starts R .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Mr. Goodkind , you do n't , mean that ! You do n't mean that because I 'm trying to help ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Help ... whom ? Strikers , and street women , and general riff-raff ! And you do n't even help them ... because nobody can ! And , if you could , and did , how in the name of God would that help the Community ? If I find you 're still crazy in half an hour , I 'll say you 're crazy , and I 'll prove it !He goes to the door .Think it over !As he is about to exit , he narrowly escapes collision with a neatly-dressed , capable-looking man , who apologizes , in nearly correct English , and , with a contemptuous glance , crosses to up C .

sp.speaker: THE MAN
sp.p: Excuse me !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: All right !He follows the man back into the room .Have n't I seen you somewhere before ?

sp.speaker: THE MAN
sp.p: Yes , sir . My name 's Umanski .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Umanski ?He remembersYou 're not the Pole who came to my house last year with a delegation ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Well , I 'll be ——DANIEL fills his pipe from a jar on the mantelpiece L .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist tell me stay in New York . He 's teach me English , and find me good job . I 'm work now eight hours on the docks , and six on myself .GOODKIND again starts to go .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Mr. Goodkind !GOODKIND turnsUmanski 's got an invention . If you 'll see it ——

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 'll see you in ... half an hour !He exits .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: What 's he doing down here , Mr. Gilchrist ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He says I 'm crazy , and he 's going to shut up this place . Of course , he wo n't .He opens a book .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Do n't be too sure .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Nonsense !He sitsI made him angry .He marks a passage .And somebody 's told him a lot of lies !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Somebody 's told a good many people lies ! Yesterday I heard a man say you run this house to ... to ...He hesitates . DAN looks up .to get women !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Who said that ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: A wop named Malduca .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , yes ! I took his daughter in here once ... for a week ... until he got sober .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: They 's a good many like that .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , not a good many !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Enough to make trouble . Why not you carry a pistol ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: It 's generally men with pistols that get shot .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: One of them fellows get you ——Enter MARY MARGARET .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Warning himSh !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I s'pose you ai n't had any supper .

lg.l: Not yet .
lg.stage: GRUBBY enters with a tray , from which MARY MARGARET transfers dishes to the table .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I brought you some money .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Money ?

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: My boss he give me another raise . He gonna make me boss after while . So I like to begin pay back what you lend me .Takes out bills .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Wait ‘ til you 've sent for your family .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I 'm gonna send now . My big boy I 'm gonna send school ... college , maybe . That pump I make she goes fine . I show my boss ... like you say ... because he know about coal mines ... and he say if she work she save whole lots of lives and money . She work , all right !He has put down the bills , and brought forth an English grammar .How about I go upstairs and study ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Sure ! Go right up to my room ! I 'll be along after the meeting !UMANSKI exits . GRUBBY starts to follow .Where are you going , Grubby ?

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Sandwiches !He exits .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Down L .Your supper 's ready !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Thanks .Looks upWhat 's this we 're wearing ? Golden slippers ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Uh-huh ! I took ‘ em out of the barrel of clothes that pretty lady sent .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Sitting at tableSupper with Cinderella !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Setting dish before himGee , I love that story !She sits beside him , facing front .When you tell it to me , you make me believe I 'm her .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: If you believe it ... you are .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I guess believin ’ ai n't never goin ’ to make me dance .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You can n't tell ... if you believe hard enough .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: That 's what you said before , and I 've tried , but , somehow , it do n't work .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's the very time to go on . If we stop , just because it do n't work , that is n't faith .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: No ; I s'pose not .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: And faith moves mountains . Once upon a time there was a woman who 'd been sick twelve years .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: What was the matter with her ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I do n't know . But there was a Man in that city who said He could even make the dead rise . And everybody laughed at Him ... as they would today . But the woman did n't laugh , and one morning , when He was passing her house , she got up and followed Him ... just to touch the hem of His cloak . And what do you think ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I duno .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: She was cured . And the Man said ——

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Oh , now , I know . “ Thy faith hath made thee whole . ”

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's right .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Could God do that for me ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: It would be an awful big favor .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: But if He does n't , you must go on . If faith does n't heal our hurts , it helps us to bear them . And that 's almost the same thing , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: DoubtfullyYes .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Like believing you 're Cinderella .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: We can n't decide what we want , and then be angry and doubtful because it does n't happen our way . Because , all the time it 's happening His way . The only thing we can be sure of is that He knows what 's best .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: That 's right .... You mean , if God wants me to be well , some day He 'll make me well ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: If you believe hard enough .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: And if He do n't ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Then that 's right ... if you believe hard enough .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I will , Mr. Gilchrist .She risesYou ai n't touched your supper .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 've had plenty .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I 'll send Grubby up for the tray .

div.stage: She exits . DANIEL finishes , and puts up his napkin . He observes that the window-shades have not been drawn . Attends to that R. Facing L ., with his hand on the shade of the window L ., he pauses to look out . PEARL HENNIG enters . Pearl is 25 , and her clothes are cheaply flashy . An experienced eye should lose no time in appraising her . She has an air of alarm . She looks around for DAN , and then is n't quite sure of him in the shadows up stage .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: UncertainlyMr. Gilchrist ?He half turnsDo n't stand by that window !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Hello , Pearl !He draws the shadeHow well you 're looking .Comes downWhat 's the matter with the window ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: It ai n't safe .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: SmilingAre you going to advise me to carry a pistol ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: No . Just to keep out o ’ sight of people that do .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Meaning ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Meaning Joe Hennig .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I thought Joe was in Black River .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: He ai n't . I told you he was ashamed to go home . I told you he was gonna stay here an ’ get you !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Sits on bench in front of tableWell ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Down stage R. of tableWell ... he stayed . I went to him ... like I told you ... an ’ said it was n't you ... an ’ ast him to take me back . An ’ he said I was a liar an ’ he was gonna get you . I told you all that !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes ; I guess you did .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: While he was workin ’ up town I did n't hear nothin ’ about him . But a little while ago he lost his job , an ’ began hangin ’ around down here . An ’ he 's been drinkin ’ , an ’ talkin ’ wild , an ’ I come in to tell you .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's kind of you , Pearl , but I 'm not afraid of Joe .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I am .... He 's got his gang .... I know .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: HesitatesWell , last night I met up with one of his pals .... An ’ he 'd been drinkin ’ . An ’ he said Joe said you was livin ’ on women , an ’ this place was a blind , an ’ nobody 's wife was safe while you was in the neighborhood . An ’ this man said they was gonna get together , an ’ drive you out . They 're dang'rous , Mr. Gilchrist . For God 's sake , believe me ! For God 's sake , telephone the police !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: There 's no telephone here , Pearl . But there 's always an officer at hand , and I 'm among friends . Do n't worry . Sit down , and wait for the meeting . I have n't seen you in ages .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Does n't sit . She is restlessTwo weeks .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What are you doing ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I 'm workin ’ at Macy 's .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Like it ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: DefiantlyBetter than bein ’ with Joe .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: If you 'd stayed with Joe , maybe he would n't be drinking .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: He always did . That 's why I ast you to stick around in Black River . That 's one reason I quit .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: One reason .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Admitting it grudginglyThey was others .... I wanted good clothes , an ’ a good time ... jus ’ like other women .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Thinking of CLAREYes ... like other women .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Indicating her costumeAn ’ I 've got ‘ em !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes ; you 've “ got ‘ em . ” But do n't you think ... sometimes ... you and the other women ... that they cost you too much ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I do n't get you .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I only mean is n't there something worth more than good clothes and a good time ? A good home , maybe , with love in it ... and little children .

div.stage: PEARL hesitates , and then the uneasiness she has never lost takes her up to peep out of the curtain .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: We ought n't to be here talkin ’ .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I 'm frightened of Joe .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You need n't be .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I am . I can n't help it . I got a hunch . I ai n't told you all this man said , an ’ I ai n't told you how he come to say it , but he said it was gonna be soon , an ’ I got a hunch sumpin 's gonna happen tonight . Please let me go out an ’ phone ! Please let me get the police !DANIEL laughsYou 're crazy , Mr. Gilchrist ! You 're just crazy !An infinitesimal pause . She turns .An ’ I 'm goin ’ !She runs to the door , which opens before her , and admits CLARE GOODKIND . CLARE is smartly gowned , in street attire , but somehow , she has the appearance of being disheveled ... of having dressed in haste .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare — Mrs. Goodkind !A pauseMrs. Hennig 's just going .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Mrs. Hennig ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Pearl Hennig . You 've heard your husband mention her name .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I know your husband .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I know you do .Her tone tells how much she knows .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: QuailsI guess you ai n't got much use for me .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Why ? What 's the difference between us ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Unable to make it outWell ... good-night !She exits .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare , I asked you ....

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'd nowhere else to go . I 've left him .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Left ... Jerry ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yes . For good . He struck me .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No ! !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Here ... in the breast ! And he 's lying now ... brandy-soaked and half-conscious ... across the foot of my bed !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I can n't ... believe ....

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: He 's been drinking ... more and more ! And , of course , there 've been women ... from the beginning ! All kinds of women ! That woman , salesgirls , stenographers , women of our own class ! Do you remember ... in your church ... a Mrs. Thornbury ? He 's been quite open about her ! Tonight we were going out to dinner ! He came to my room ... drunk ... and babbled that he 'd refused to go until she was invited ! Then I refused to go , and he accused me ... of you ... and struck me with his fist !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He accused ... you ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Yes . And then he tried to take me in his arms ! Night after night he 's come to me ... drunk ... and held me in his arms . And I said once there was nothing more degrading than poverty ! In the past two years I 've learned what degradation means ! I 've come to see your way at last ! I 've come to realize that the material things are nothing , and that love is all ! It is n't too late ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: It 's never too late !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I knew you 'd say that ! I 'll share your work ... your want ... if need be ... gladly ! Only take me away !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Not yet comprehendingBut my work is here !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: We can n't stay here ! Jerry suspects us ! He 's made his father suspect us ! Do you know what they 're planning to do now ?He nodsJerry wants to send you to an asylum ! He said so tonight ! And he 'll do it , too ! The strange thing about Jerry is that , with his mind going , and his health gone , he still gets what he wants ! Take me away , and “ we 'll have five or six rooms , and each other ! ”

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Do n't you understand that I 'm offering myself to you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes ; I understand !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I love you ! I need you ! I 've always loved you , and needed you , even when I lied to you , and myself ! This is our last chance for happiness ! I 've been blind , and stupid , and cruel , but it is n't too late ! Take me , and hold me , and we 'll both forget !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Forget ?

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Forget everything ! Wo n't you take me , dear ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Do n't you want me ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: That 's not true ! You love me ! You 've always loved me ! Look at me , and deny it if you can !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I do n't deny it ! I love you !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Then take me !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I love the good in you ... the good you 're trying so hard to kill ! I love you because you 're big enough to do what 's right !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: What is right ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Go back to your husband !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I 'd rather die !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 'd rather you died ... than this !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Oh , you fanatic ! You blind fanatic !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I love you !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Love ! You do n't know what love means ! You 're only half a man !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: And I 'm praying to God , with all my strength , to save us from the other half !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: For what ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: For you ... and HIM ... and for MY PEOPLE .Off R ., very softly , as she goes down the hall , MARY MARGARET is heard singing “ I 'm a Pilgrim ; I 'm a Stranger . ”For the little girl out there .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: And for them you 'd send me back to degradation ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That little girl 's known degradation that you and I will never know . And she 's singing . Her constant companions are poverty and pain . And she 's singing . She 's crippled . She may never walk again . And still she can say God 's will be done . She believes in me . I can n't disappoint her and the rest . I 'm going on with my job , and you 're going back to yours !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You mean to Jerry ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You think that 's God 's will ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I know it 's your job . You took it with your eyes open . It 's up to you to see it through .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Must I go on forever paying for one mistake ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Somebody must pay for our mistakes . That it was wrong to make a bargain does n't make it right to break the bargain when we get tired of it .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: I do n't know what to do .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Play the game . Go back to that poor , mistaken man lying across the foot of your bed — his mind going and his health gone . Bear your punishment and help him to bear his . That 's your duty !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Duty ! Duty !! What about happiness ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: There is no other happiness . Oh , do n't you see , my dear , that 's been your great mistake ? You 're always crying — you and the world — “ I want to be happy ! ” Happiness is service ! Happiness is clean-living , and clear-thinking , and self-forgetfulness , and self-respect !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: And love ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Love is n't all . Not the love you mean . You said : “ Take me , and we 'll both forget . ” Could we have forgotten promises unkept , faith disappointed , aspirations unrealized ? No , my dear , love is n't all ; nor even happiness . There 's something bigger , and better , and more important , and that something is ... DUTY !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: The world does n't think that !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's what 's wrong with the world !A pause .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: You want me to go back ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I want you to be right !

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: Well , then ... I 'm going through . I 'm going back , and play the game ... with you in my heart always . You do n't forbid that , do you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You are in mine always .

sp.speaker: CLARE
sp.p: And this is n't good-bye . Sometime ... somewhere ... in this world ... or out of it ... there must be a moment ... and a place ... to retrieve mistakes .... Good-night .

div.stage: She starts up . He passes her , and opens the door .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Clare ... good-night .She takes his hand . Then she exits . The outer door slams . Then a cab door ... faintly . He sinks ... tired with the effort of renunciation . Afterward he comes down , slowly , and drops on the bench in front of the table . MARY MARGARET enters , singing “ I 'm a Pilgrim , ” in a higher key , to march tempo , keeping time with her crutches . She is down R. when she sees DANIEL .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Ai n't you well , Mr. Gilchrist ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Just tired .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Maybe you ai n't believin ’ hard enough .He looks up .It 's ‘ most time for the meetin ’ .GRUBBY enters with a tray .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: I brung the sandwiches .

div.stage: MRS. MULLIGAN enters . She is the worse for liquor , and glad of a warm place to enjoy it . She slinks in rather furtively , and sits R. end of table . She is followed on by MR. and MRS. HENCHLEY . He is a middle-aged and respectable locksmith . She is larger than he , and somewhat formidable .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Good evening , Mrs. Mulligan .

sp.speaker: MRS. MULLIGAN
sp.p: With a hiccoughIt is not !

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Aside to MARY MARGARETBums ... like that ... ai n't got no business here .

sp.speaker: MR. HENCHLEY
sp.p: Good evening , Mary Margaret .She nods .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENCHLEY
sp.p: Good evening , Mr. Gilchrist .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Good evening , and welcome .

sp.speaker: MR. HENCHLEY
sp.p: To DANIELI guess we 're early .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENCHLEY
sp.p: To DANIELYes . I wanted to speak to you ... about Mr. Henchley 's pants .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Mr. Henchley 's what ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENCHLEY
sp.p: Pants . I took out a spot ... with gasoline ... and hung ‘ em on the fire-escape that runs across from this house , and tonight they was gone , and I think you ought to look into your lodgers .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I will .

div.stage: Enter MISS LEVINSON . She is a Jewess — a garment-worker ; thoughtful , studious , spectacled .

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: Good evening , everybody !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Good evening , Miss Levinson .

div.stage: The others , too , acknowledge the greeting .

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: I 've brought back your book .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENCHLEY
sp.p: What 've you been reading ?

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: George Bernard Shaw .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENCHLEY
sp.p: I s'pose you ai n't read “ The Sheik ” ?

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: With justifiable prideI 've been reading “ Cæsar and Cleopatra . ”

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Taking the volumeThat 's where we got the quotation on the board . I 've jumbled it a bit .Reads“ And so , to the end of history , hate shall breed hate , murder shall breed murder , until the gods create a race that can understand . ”

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: That 's it ; is n't it ? A race that can —

div.stage: The door is opened violently , and enter PEARL HENNIG .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , Pearl ; I thought you 'd gone .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: No ; I 've been watchin ’ , an ’ I 've got to speak to you ... quick !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: In just a few minutes .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Now ! Joe 's out there !

sp.speaker: MRS. MULLIGAN
sp.p: Ah , shut up !

lg.l: Mrs . Mulligan !... Pearl ; you 're interrupting !... You were saying , Miss
Levinson ?

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: We seem always to have hated everything different from ourselves ... in station , or race , or religion .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Yes . It 's stupid ... and instinctive . I 've noticed we 're inclined to blame a man for a pug nose ... if ours is Roman . Some day we 'll get over the idea that all who differ from us are villains , and that we should hate each other instead of trying to understand each other . It was on the battlefields that I came to believe a man 's life might well be given to teaching and to preaching ... love !A solid half-brick crashes through a practical pane of glass in the window L. Everybody screams and rises .Do n't be alarmed . It 's only some hoodlum !

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist ... it 's Joe ! I seen him in front ! That 's why I could n't get out ! Somebody go get the police !A general movement .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: He 's got other men with him ! He 'll kill you !The front door slams . Pearl hurls herself against the door R .Here he comes ! Do n't let him in ! Somebody help me hold this door !In spite of her , the door slowly opens .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Pearl ! Stand aside !Enter GOODKIND .It 's only Mr. Goodkind !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Yes . And your neighbors are calling .

sp.speaker: MR. HENCHLEY
sp.p: What 's the matter ?Together

sp.speaker: MRS. HENCHLEY
sp.p: Is there any danger ?Together

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I 'll get the cops .Together

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: Off stageThe fake ! The damned pimp ! Drive him out ! Come on .... Rush him !

div.stage: Suddenly there is the noise of the oncoming . PEARL throws herself before DAN . MARY MARGARET is just behind him . The others retreat to the platform . Headed by JOE HENNIG ... drunk ... the rowdies enter — JIMMIE CURRAN , a big dockman , his wife and half a dozen hangers-on of the neighborhood .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: En routeCome on , fellows ! We 'll show this guy ! We 'll show —He confronts themBy God ! Caught in the act !To his gangThat 's my wife !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Caught in what act , Joe ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Why ... caught ... in the act ....

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Tell him what we 're here for .... You , Grubby .

sp.speaker: GRUBBY
sp.p: Following the example of PETERI don ’ want to get in no trouble !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I 'll tell you .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No , Mary Margaret !

lg.stage: Who has come through the crowd unobserved ; claps his hand on JOE 'S shoulder , forcing him to his knees
lg.l: : I tell you !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Umanski !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: I tell you , Hennig ! Mr. Gilchrist been friend to everybody ! And now , when he need friend , nobody knows nothing ! Well , I know ! I know anybody hurt him gotta lick me !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No ... please ... Umanski !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Lickin ’ people ai n't gonna hide facks !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Threatening with his free fistShall I ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No ... no !

div.stage: UMANSKI sets JOE on his feet . JOE turns eloquently to his gang .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I 'll show you the kind of fake that 's been foolin ’ you ! He was a preacher , an ’ he got kicked out of his church !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: Kicked out ! They got onto you , did they ? Caught him with the goods !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: He was a spy for the people that live on labor , and he came to the mines , where we was on strike , and ran away with my wife !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: The dirty bum ! Maybe he did n't get much !

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: It was n't him !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: She says that ‘ cause she 's stuck on him !

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: I ai n't !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Well , you 're workin ’ for him , ai n't you ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Your wife 's working in a store uptown !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: We know different ! What 's she doing here ? That 's a good one ! What 're you giving us ? Everybody in the neighborhood knows what she 's doing !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: My wife 's walking the streets !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's a lie !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I heard from a pal she picked up las ’ night ... an ’ I seen her comin ’ here !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: She 's workin ’ Sixth Avenue !

sp.speaker: MRS. MULLIGAN
sp.p: I can n't believe it ! I can n't believe it !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Pearl !!!... It is a lie ?

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Oh , no !... It 's true .A momentary silence ; the gang jeers ; she turns on them ; then a momentary defiance .Well ! Well , why would n't it be ? I tried to live straight ... like you told me ... an ’ I had a job ... but when the other girls got wise .... They ai n't no better than I am !She slowly gives way before his calm , steady gaze .Anyway ... I lied . I am walkin ’ the streets . I ai n't no good . I ai n't fit to live .She starts to sink at his feet . He raises her .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Pearl !

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: For Christ 's sake , ai n't you done with me now ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: For Christ 's sake ... no !And he takes her in his arms .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: It 's all fake ! Ai n't you fellows on ? He 's got every rotten woman in the neighborhood workin ’ for him . Your wives ai n't safe ! Your kids ai n't safe ! Ask Jimmie Curran ! He knows what 's goin ’ on here !Enter TONY MALDUCA .Ask Tony Malduca !

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Here 's Tony !

sp.speaker: TONY
sp.p: Why you send for me ? What do you want ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: We want to know what happened to your kid ! Did he bring her in here ... an ’ keep her ... against her will ? Did he ?

sp.speaker: TONY
sp.p: That 's what he done !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: You remember Teresa Malduca ? You see ! Sure ; everybody knows that ! She was here a week !

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: You damned wop !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Umanski !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: There ai n't no woman safe ! He 's a damned fake ! Beat him up ! Kill him !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: That 's it ! Do n't let this big guy buffalo you ! Come on ! Drive him out !To DANIELI said I 'd get you , an ’ I have !The gang presses closer , but UMANSKI 'S menacing bulk still holds them off .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Kneeling on the platform L .Oh , dear God , please listen !And she begins the Lord 's Prayer .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Get the police !

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: Crying out of the window L .Police ! Police !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: To UMANSKIGet out of the way ... you !

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Bust him in the jaw !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Forcing his way throughListen to me ! No violence ! You 're dealing with a lunatic ! Leave him alone ! I 've got a doctor coming in a few minutes ! Leave him to me , and I give you my word I 'll have this place closed tonight !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: Yes , and he 'll open another one ! Sure he will ! Of course he will ! Ah-h-h ! Beat him up !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Leave him alone ! You can n't beat a crazy man !

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist ai n't crazy ! He ai n't a man ! Ai n't you seen what he just done to me ?

sp.speaker: A WOMAN
sp.p: Hire a hall !All laugh .

sp.speaker: PEARL
sp.p: Ai n't you heard ? I lied to him , an ’ he 's give me another chance , an ’ I 'm gonna take it ! He ai n't no man ! He 's a Saint ! I tell you he 's like God !

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Where 's his wings ?All laugh .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Like God !

sp.speaker: JIMMIE
sp.p: That 's blasphemy !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: That 's what it is , an ’ that 's what he 's been tellin ’ ‘ em ! Ai n't it ... you ... Grubby ? Did n't he tell you that , Jimmie ? Did n't he tell you he was a Son of God ?

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: Sure he did ! That 's right !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You see , that 's what he 's told ‘ em all ! That 's how he gets ‘ em !To DANIELDid n't you tell ‘ em you was a Son of God ?There is a momentary silence , broken only by MARY MARGARET 'S prayer .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I am !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: He admits it ! And I 'm Mary Magdalene ! Pipe Mary Magdalene ! Son of God !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: And so are we all !JeersIn you ... and me ... and all of us ... deep down ... is something of Him ! We may try to hide it —Jeers— or kill it , but , in spite of ourselves , we are Divine !

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE GANG
sp.p: Chuck it ! Hell ! Cut the gab ! He 's crazy ! Come on ; smash the place !

sp.speaker: TONY
sp.p: Facing DANIELIf you 're a Son of God ... save yourself ! If you 're ... what you say ... give us a sign !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Ah , hell ! Come on !

div.stage: Two men have climbed upon the table , and suddenly seize UMANSKI from behind . Momentarily , they bear him down , and this obstacle is removed . As they drag him up R ., the rest of the gang closes in from all sides , hiding Daniel , who is forced up stage C. The table is overturned . Above the struggling mass are seen fists striking down , various improvised weapons in action . A Dockman , who , at JOE 'S speech , has lifted the bench from behind DANIEL , to fell him with it , and whose weapon has been seized , from the rear , by the HENCHLEYS , pommels madly . Above the pandemonium are distinguished voices — PEARL : “ Help ! ” UMANSKI : “ I kill somebody ! ” MISS LEVINSON : “ Police ! ” GOODKIND : “ Let him alone ! ” Suddenly UMANSKI throws off his captors , and , attacking the mob from in front , mows his way through , tossing them to left and right . When a way is cleared , he ... and we ... see DANIEL , senseless , lying in the overturned table , a tiny trickle of blood running down his face , his head supported by the table-leg R. UMANSKI gives a deep groan of rage and pity . Hearing this and divining that something dreadful has happened to her hero , MARY MARGARET , who has ceased praying , and raised herself to her feet by the aid of a neighboring chair , walks down to L. C. Before she sees DANIEL , MISS LEVINSON sees her , and emits a piercing scream .

sp.speaker: MISS LEVINSON
sp.p: Mary Margaret ! Where are your crutches ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Looking at her legs in tearful bewildermentI do n't know !She tries them ; then , in an hysterical cryI kin walk ! I kin walk !She looks for her benefactor ... to show him .Mr. Gilchrist ! Mr. Gilchrist !The crowd parts , and she sees the figure lying against the overturned table .Oh , Mr. Gilchrist !She folds him in her arms .

sp.speaker: UMANSKI
sp.p: Staring at MARY MARGARET , and in a tone of hushed aweYou wanted a sign — LOOK ! Down on your knees — you murderers ! God 's in this room ! Down on your knees !

div.stage: One by one and two by two , the frightened mob obeys . JOE is lying senseless , but his cohorts , crossing themselves , have seen a miracle .
THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT IV .

stage.stage: SCENE : Gilchrist 's Room — “ Upstairs . ” Two months later .

The room is cheerful . That is its chief aspect . Cheerful , and comfortable , and homelike . Such a room ... in the rear of the fourth story ... might be had anywhere for seven dollars a week , and its contents duplicated for a couple of hundred , yet no one should be able to look in without envying the occupant . Before the warm glow of a fireplace down R. is a big , brown leather-covered armchair . An electric lamp stands on a table stage left of the chair and squarely opposite the fireplace . There are books on the table , too , and writing things , and another chair on its left . Above the grate a picture of Christ in the Temple . Conspicuous in the flat , and visible from all parts of the house , a big studio window . There are cream-colored outside curtains , and brown denim inside curtains , drawn now , but when they are pulled aside , one sees chimney-pots , and roof-tops , and a blue night-sky , with one particularly bright star . Up L ., a curtained arch into a hall bedroom , and down L. a door . The walls , covered with old-gold grass-cloth , are hidden , to a height of six feet , by roughly-built bookcases , filled with much-used books . A sofa , against the wall L ., now holds numerous packages . There is a brown-and-tan grass rug on the floor , and there may be a window seat , with brown cushions , beneath the window . The furniture is all old ... probably second-hand ... but , as aforesaid , the room suggests comfort and peace .

sp.speaker: AT RISE : It is just after eight o'clock , Christmas Eve ,
sp.p: 1920 . DANIEL is discovered , dreaming , in the armchair R ., a pipe in his mouth and his face to the fire . He has not lighted the desk lamp , and , except for the glow of the embers , the room is in darkness . Hanging over the left arm of the chair , DANIEL 'S hand holds a magazine , but he has not begun reading . After a pause long enough for the audience to take in his surroundings , there is a light tap at the door and , without waiting for a response , MARY MARGARET enters . She walks without crutches — quite briskly — but plainly is on some secret business . Daniel is lost in the darkness . A package in her hand , MARY MARGARET crosses quickly to the table , and turns on one and then the other of the two lights in the lamp . Instantly , of course , she sees the figure in the chair , and conceals the package beneath her apron .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Mr. Gilchrist ?He shows himselfGoo'ness , how you scared me ! I thought you went out !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: No ; I just slipped up here to read a while before we put our gifts on the tree .... Where 's Grubby ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: ContemptuouslyGrubby !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: He promised to help with the packages .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Grubby 's all swelled up with his new taxicab . Christmas Eve 's the big night in his business , but he says do n't worry ... he 'll be here in time for the sandwiches . Am I interruptin ’ your readin ’ ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Oh , no ! What have you there ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Under your apron .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Oh !

div.stage: She reveals the parcel ] I was gonna surprise you . It 's your Christmas present .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: From you ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Handing it across the tableYes . It ai n't much ... you know ... an ’ I did n't want it on the tree ... before everybody . I wanted to give it to you myself . Open it now .He does so . The package contains a framed picture .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Mary Margaret !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: The name 's on the back !He turns it around , revealing to the audience a cheap and highly-colored chromoSee ... “ Mama 's Treasure . ”

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: It 's just what I wanted .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: DelightedIs it ... honest ?... Let 's put it in place of that one over the mantel-piece ! That 's an awful pretty pitcher , but mine 's got colors in it !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Why not in place of the Venus who fell on her nose ?

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Oh , yes !She stands “ Mama 's Treasure ” atop a bookcase L .It looks good , do n't it ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Beautiful . I can n't thank you enough .Takes her handI can n't really .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: You can n't thank me ! You that 's give me —She looks down at her legs , and up again with eyes full of tearsOh , Mr. Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Now ! Now ! Now ! We must n't cry on Christmas !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: What 're you going to do if you 're happy ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Try laughing .She doesAnyway , if I 'm having my Christmas now , you must have yours . Suppose you rummage on the sofa .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Oh !She runs to obey , and holds up a parcel inquiringly .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: That 's a book for Miss Levinson .

lg.l: Mrs. Henchley .
This one ai n't marked .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Gloves for Mack . I wanted to show I appreciated his bringing back that coat .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Reading from two packagesPeter ... Paul ....

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: For your brothers .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: With a fourthAnd ... Mary Margaret !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Open it now .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Breathless , she comes to him C. Hesitates , and then , removing the wrapping , reveals a child 's set in beaver — muff and neckpieceOh , Mr. Gilchrist !She tries themOh , Mr. Gilchrist ; you ought n't !Looks about for a mirrorThey 're beautiful ! They 're the most beautifulest furs I ever seen ! I 've wanted a set like this always ! You 've made me so happy ! I never was so happy before in my life !And she begins to cry again .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Now !She remembers , and laughs .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I do n't know how to thank you .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Do n't try .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I never expected no such a Christmas !Starts for doorI gotta show mother !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Turning R .Take down a few of the packages !

lg.l: I 'll be back in a minute !
lg.stage: She opens the door , disclosing GOODKIND . Seriously alarmed
lg.l: Oh !... Mr. Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Turning L .Well ... Mr. Goodkind !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: May I come in ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Of course !He enters . Dan indicates chair L. of table R .Sit down !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 've only a moment . Jerry 's waiting for me in the car .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: How is Jerry ?MARY MARGARET arranges the chair .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Shakes his head despairingly . Looks at MARY MARGARETI wish you could perform a miracle on him .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I wish I could .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: To MARY MARGARETYou seem to walk all right .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: Oh , yes !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: To DANHad a doctor look her over ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Three of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Any opinion ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Three opinions .

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: They said he did n't do it , and you seen him !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Holds up a warning fingerSsh !Then to GOODKINDThey all say she suffered from hysterical paraplegia .GOODKIND puzzledHysterical paralysis . One says she was cured by shock — you know ; the riot . Another says it was suggestion ... believing ... which is another way of saying faith , is n't it ? The important thing is that she 's cured !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: God did it — God and Mr. Gilchrist !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Hushing her againTake down an armful of those packages ... like a good girl !

sp.speaker: MARY MARGARET
sp.p: I will .She gathers them up , and , returning L. C ., looks apprehensively at GOODKINDYou call ... if you want me !Exits

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Hesitates . Does n't know how to begin . Takes cigars from his pocketSmoke ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Thanks .Showing his pipeI 'll stick to my old friend .He sits .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: How are things with you ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: EnthusiasticallyFine !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Happy ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: RadiantlyYes !... And you ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: No . Everything 's ... all wrong . My boy 's very ill. Clare 's wonderful to him . I can n't explain it — she 's like a different woman . And she seems happy . But Jerry 's had to give up work , and there 's more trouble in Black River , and that 's what brought me !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: You do n't want my advice ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I want you ... as general manager . These strikes are such utter damned waste ! We had a working compromise on your agreement , and everything was all right , but we began figuring we could make more money ... and the men walked out , and flooded the mines . I 'd like you to take charge , Daniel .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I can n't .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Name your own salary .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: My work is here .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You can have anything you want .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I do n't want anything .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You want to see the men get their rights .

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: They 'll get ‘ em . Nothing can stop that .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: You 're not going to turn down fifty thousand dollars a year ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What can I buy with it that I have n't got ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: What can you buy with fifty ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: What have you bought ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 've got one of the finest houses in New York !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Is it any more comfortable than this ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: This one little room !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: How many rooms do you live in at the same time ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 've got half a dozen cars !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: I 've two legs , and I walk , and keep well .

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: I 've twenty servants ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Do n't tell me you enjoy that !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And the respect of people about me ——

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: So have I !

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: And , what 's most important of all , I 'm a success !

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Are you ?

sp.speaker: GOODKIND
sp.p: Huh ?

sp.speaker: DANIEL
sp.p: Are you ? What is success ? Money ? Yes ; that 's what our civilization tells us . Money ! But where has that brought us ? Only to the elevation of the unfit ... the merely shrewd and predatory . All around us we see men of wealth who have nothing else ... neither health nor happiness nor love nor respect .
